Monologion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: omnipotentem bonitatem suam dantem et facientem
Monologion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm attributes all goodness to the "omnipotent goodness" of God, echoing Genesis 1:31 where God looks upon his creation and declares it good, linking divine power with the bestowal of goodness.

The phrase “the highest of all that exists” mirrors Psalm 145:3’s description of the Lord as “great above all” (Magnus Dominus, et laudabilis in infinitum), presenting God as the supreme summit of being.

Monologion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: per omnia bona, si ad invicem conferantur, aut aequaliter aut inacqualiter sint bona
Monologion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s discussion that all good is measured by its relation to a single source recalls 1 John 4:8, “God is love,” where love (the ultimate good) is the standard by which all other goods are judged.

The notion that everything is ultimately good reflects Romans 8:28’s promise that “all things work together for good” for those who are in God, suggesting a universal orientation toward the divine good.

Monologion:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that something is “good in itself” echoes Psalm 145:9 (Vulgate) “Bonum est Dominus omnibus…”, where the Lord is presented as the ultimate good, good in and of Himself.
The reference to wisdom as the highest good mirrors Proverbs 9:10 “Timor Domini initium sapientiae”, a biblical theme that wisdom (and the fear of the Lord) is the supreme good.

Monologion:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non potest esse summe magnum nisi id quod est summe bonum
Monologion:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s equation of the supremely great with the supremely good reflects Deuteronomy 10:17, which declares that God is “the great, and terrible, and a God of truth, who keeps covenant and loving‑kindness, and does not deal in falsehood.” The verse links God’s greatness with His perfect goodness.
The idea that the ultimate good is good in itself resonates with 1 John 4:8 (“Deus est caritas”), where God’s nature is identified with love/goodness, though the wording is not a direct quotation.

Monologion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: per quod sunt cuncta quae sunt
Monologion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase mirrors John 1:3 “per quod omnia facta sunt” (by which all things were made), echoing the same concept that all things exist through a single principle.

Monologion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: cuncta quae sunt, sunt per ipsum unum
Monologion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that everything that exists is through ‘that one’ reflects John 1:3’s claim that “by Him all things were made,” extending the Johannine Logos‑creation motif.

Monologion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quod autem maxime omnium est, et per quod est quidquid est bonum uel magnum
Monologion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s identification of the highest principle as the source of all good and great parallels James 1:17, which states that every good and perfect gift comes from above.

Monologion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Cum enim dominus et seruus referantur ad invicem
Monologion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The juxtaposition of ‘Lord and servant’ evokes Philippians 2:7, where Christ, though in the form of God, took the form of a servant, suggesting a relational hierarchy similar to Anselm’s discussion of reference.

Monologion:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quod enim non est, a quo faciente aut ex qua materia aut quibus adiumentis ad esse peruenerit: id uidetur aut esse nihil, aut si aliquid est, per nihil esse et ex nihilo.
Monologion:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s discussion of something existing “ex nihilo” mirrors the biblical doctrine of creation out of nothing found in Genesis 1:1 (“In principio Deus creavit caelum et terram”).
The phrase “ex nihilo” echoes Psalm 33:6 in the Vulgate – “Ex nihilo fecit nos” – which celebrates God’s creative act from nothing.

Monologion:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: …quod enim non est, a quo faciente…
Monologion:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s reference to “a quo faciente” (the one who makes) recalls John 1:3: “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum est nihil.”

Monologion:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: At nullum bonum potest intelligi ante illud bonum, sine quo nihil est bonum.
Monologion:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that no good can be understood apart from the supreme good reflects Psalm 145:9 – “Bonum est Dominus, et omnis benevolentia eius.”

Monologion:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quia namque ad magnum et delectabile quiddam me subito perduxit haec mea meditatio…
Monologion:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The language of “magnum et delectabile” (great and delightful) evokes Psalm 145:3 – “Magnus Dominus, et laudabilis valde; et magna est gloria eius.”

Monologion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non dubito omnem hanc mundi molem cum partibus suis sicut uidemus formatam, constare ex terra et aqua et aere et igne
Monologion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s enumeration of the four basic elements echoes the Genesis creation narrative (Gen 1:1‑2) where God brings forth earth, water, air (spirit) and fire (light), though the elements are not listed verbatim in the Vulgate.

Monologion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quapropter quoniam omne quod aliud est quam ipsa, minus est ipsa, impossibile est aliquid aliud hoc modo esse ex ipsa.
Monologion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that the supreme good cannot be altered or diminished reflects Malachi 3:6 “Ego Dominus, non mutabor” – God is immutable and cannot be less than Himself.

Monologion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quippe nihil omnino uel cogitari potest esse praeter illud summum omnium, quod est per seipsum
Monologion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s assertion that only the “summum omnium” (the highest of all) exists by itself parallels Psalm 90:2’s description of God as “aeternus… per se” – the self‑existent, eternal One.
The phrase “ex nulla materia” paraphrases the doctrine of creation ex nihilo implicit in Genesis 2:4 (“in principio Deus creavit…”) where all things arise from no pre‑existing material.

Monologion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nullatenus est bonum, per quod mutatur uel corrumpitur summum bonum
Monologion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that the supreme good cannot be corrupted mirrors 1 John 4:8 (“Deus caritas est”) which presents God (the ultimate good) as immutable and pure.

Monologion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nihil fit ex nihilo, sicut uox omnium est: quia de nihilo nihil.
Monologion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm re‑states John 1:3 (Vulgate: “sine ipso nihil factum est”) in his own words, asserting that nothing comes into being from nothing.
The clause echoes the same Johannine claim that all things are made through the Word, i.e., not from nothing, but Anselm phrases it as a question about “ex nihilo aliquid efficiatur”.

Monologion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ex nihilo … quod nullum habebat esse … adiuuit aliquid … ut perveniret ad esse
Monologion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s whole discussion of whether something can arise from nothing reflects the Genesis 1:1 doctrine that God created the heavens and the earth “in the beginning”, a foundational scriptural theme of creation ex nihilo.

Monologion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that before things were made there was ‘nothing’ echoes the biblical doctrine of creation ex nihilo expressed in Genesis 1:1 – “In principio Deus creavit caelum et terram.”
The notion of a supreme rational principle existing before all things parallels John 1:1‑3, where the Logos (Word) is the “principium” and “per quod omnia facta sunt.”

Monologion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: per quod et secundum quod fierent
Monologion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrasing mirrors John 1:3’s wording “per quod omnia facta sunt, et sine ipso factum non est nihil,” directly linking the creative act to a rational cause.

Monologion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formulation that “He says what He will do” mirrors the creation formula in Genesis 1:3 where God says “Let there be…”, indicating that divine speech precedes the act of creation.

Monologion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non immerito uideri potest apud summam substantian, talem rerum locutionem et fuisse antequam essent ut per eam fierent, et esse cum facta sunt ut per eam sciantur.
Monologion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage echoes John 1:1‑3 (“In the beginning was the Word… all things were made through Him”) by asserting that a “word‑like” locution existed before things and that things are known through it after they are made.

Monologion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: per corporis imaginem, ut cum eius sensibilem figuram imaginatur
Monologion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s reference to knowing a thing “by the image of the body” recalls Genesis 1:26 where humanity is created “in the image (imago) of God,” linking the concept of image with cognition.
The idea that things are brought into being by a mental conception parallels Psalm 33:6, “By the word of the Lord the heavens were made,” i.e., creation by divine utterance.

Monologion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et esse cum facta sunt ut per eam sciantur.
Monologion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that things exist and are known “through the word” after they are made reflects John 1:14, “The Word became flesh and dwelt among us,” emphasizing the Word as the means of revelation.

Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quasi dixisse cunctam creaturam, quam eam secundum eandem et per eandem suam intimam locutionem conderet
Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of the whole creation being brought into being by the “intima locutio” (the intimate word) mirrors John 1:3 – “per ipsum facta sunt omnia, et sine ipso factum est nihil quod factum est.”

Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Illa namque nihil omnino aliunde assumpsit, unde uel eorum quae factura erat formam in seipsa compingeret, uel ea ipsa hoc quod sunt perficeret.
Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that the Creator “assumed nothing from elsewhere” reflects the doctrine of creation ex nihilo expressed in Genesis 1:1 – “In principio creavit Deus caelum et terram.”

Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quapropter ea quae per illam creata sunt, omnino non sunt aliquid quod non sunt per: illam;
Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s statement that all things created through the divine “are not something that exists apart from her” parallels Colossians 1:16 – “per ipsum omnia facta sunt, quae in caelis et quae in terra.”

Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quare in hoc differunt ab inuicem illae in creatrice substantia et in fabro suorum operum faciendorum intimae locutiones, quod illa nec assumpta nec adinta aliunde sed prima et sola causa sufficere potuit suo artifici ad suum opus perficiendum
Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The contrast between the divine Creator (the “prima et sola causa”) and the human craftsman echoes Psalm 33:6 – “Per verbum Domini caeli facti sunt, et omnis virtus eorum.”

Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Faber uero penitus nec mente potest aliquid corporeum imaginando concipere, nisi id quod aut totum simul aut per partes ex aliquibus rebus aliquomodo iam didicit;
Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The image of a craftsman who can only fashion what he has previously known resembles Proverbs 8:30 – “Quae posuit fundamenta terrae, non est quod possit inveniri.”

Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nec opus mente conceptum perficere, si desit aut materia aut aliquid sine quo opus praecogitatum fieri non possit.
Monologion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The insistence that a work cannot be completed without material or a pre‑existing cause reflects Hebrews 1:10 – “In principio posui terram super caelos, et formavi illam.”

Monologion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: per suam intimam locutionem fecit, siue singula singulis uerbis, siue potius uno uerbo simul omnia dicendo
Monologion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of God creating through “his intimate speech, either word by word or by one word all at once” mirrors John 1:3 – “per ipsum facta sunt omnia” – the doctrine that all things were made through the Word.

Monologion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quidquid summa substantia fecit, non fecit per aliud quam per semetipsam
Monologion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The phrasing echoes Psalm 115:3 “Dominus ipse est Deus, ipse fecit nos, et non nos ipsi,” stressing that the supreme being creates by himself and not through any other agent.

Monologion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et quod fecit, per suam intimam locutionem… uno uerbo simul omnia dicendo
Monologion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s image of creation by a single spoken word parallels Genesis 1:3 where God says “Fiat lux” and light appears, emphasizing creation by divine utterance.

Monologion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summae essentiae locutionem non esse aliud quam summam essentiam
Monologion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The identification of the “speech of the supreme essence” with the “summum essentia” recalls John 1:1’s declaration “In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum,” linking the Word and divine essence.

Monologion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: cuncta quae facta sunt, eodem ipso sustinente uigent et perseuerant esse
Monologion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that all created things endure by the same sustaining being echoes Hebrews 1:3, which describes God as the one who “sustains all things by his powerful word.”

Monologion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nihil factum est nisi per creatricem praesentem essentiam
Monologion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The statement that nothing was made except through a present creator mirrors John 1:3 (and Colossians 1:16), which affirms that “all things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made that was made.”

Monologion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nihil uigeat nisi per eiusdem seruatricem praesentiam
Monologion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s insistence that nothing endures except by the same preserving presence parallels John 15:4‑5, where Christ says that those who abide in Him “shall also abide in Him,” linking endurance to the continual presence of the divine.

The phrase “by one something” can be read as an echo of 1 Cor 8:6, which affirms that there is “one God, the Father, from whom are all things,” suggesting a unity of the principle that sustains all things.

Monologion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Ubique igitur est et per omnia et in omnibus.
Monologion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the ultimate principle is everywhere mirrors Psalm 139:7‑12, where the psalmist declares that God is present wherever one may go, emphasizing divine omnipresence.

Monologion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ubi ipsa non est, nihil sit
Monologion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The formulation that where the principle is not, nothing exists echoes John 1:3 – “All things were made through Him, and without Him nothing was made.” Anselm re‑words the same logical claim about the necessity of the divine source for all being.

Monologion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ex qua et per quam et in qua omnia
Monologion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of the principle as that “from which, through which, and in which all things exist” parallels Colossians 1:17, which states that Christ is “before all things, and in Him all things hold together.”
The pairing of “creator” and “sustainer” (creans et fouens) recalls Hebrews 1:3, where the Son “sustains all things by the word of his power,” linking creation with ongoing support.

Monologion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nullatenus aliquid creatum potest exire creantis et fouentis immensitatem
Monologion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that nothing created can escape the creator’s (and sustainer’s) immensity reflects the Genesis creation motif (In principio creavit Deus…); Anselm expands the notion of God’s creative power to include an inescapable containment.

Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Melius est homini esse non aurum quam aurum
Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm re‑states the proverb that wisdom (or the good) is better than gold; the Vulgate reads “Melius est sapientia quam aurum, et sapientia melior est quam argentum.”

Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Melius est sapiens quam non sapiens
Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the proverb “Melius est sapientia quam gemmae pretiosae” (Vulgate: “Melius est sapientia quam gemmae pretiosae”), i.e. wisdom is better than any non‑wise thing.

Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summum … non simpliciter significat illam essentiam quae omnimodo maior et melior est
Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Reflects the biblical theme that God is “maior est Dominus quam omnes dii” – the highest being is understood as greater and better than all that is not that being.
Alludes to the creation narrative “In principio creavit Deus caelum et terram” – the notion of a creator of the whole universe.

Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nullum eorum substantiale est illi de quo relatiue dicitur
Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Parallels John 1:3 “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum est nihil” – nothing has substance apart from the Creator.

Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non est per aliud quam per seipsam
Monologion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Resembles the self‑identifying formula of God “Ego sum qui sum,” indicating that the ultimate reality is self‑existent and not derived from anything else.

Monologion:16:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summa vita, ... summa ueritas, ... summa sapientia
Monologion:16:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm lists the highest "life, truth, wisdom" which echoes the Johannine formula "I am the way, the truth, and the life" (Ioannes 14,6). The parallel of three supreme perfections suggests a deliberate biblical resonance.
The emphasis on supreme justice recalls Psalm 89:14 – "Iustitia et iustitiae tuae regnum tuum" – where justice (iustitia) is presented as a fundamental attribute of God’s reign.
Anselm’s mention of incorruptibility resonates with Malachi 3:6’s declaration that the LORD does not change, implying divine immutability and incorruptibility.
The phrase “summa unitas” (the highest unity) evokes the Shema’s affirmation of the oneness of God: "Dominus Deus tuus, Dominus unus est" (Deuteronomy 6:4).
Anselm’s description of the supreme power of the highest nature parallels Revelation 1:8, where God declares, "Ego sum Alpha et Omega, principis et finis, Deus omnipotens" – the Almighty.
The attribute of incorruptibility recalls Hebrews 12:1’s image of the "incorruptible crown" that believers run toward, suggesting a biblical metaphor for an unchanging, perfect nature.

Monologion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quia quidquid est, per illa est, et illa quod sunt, per illud non sunt
Monologion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formulation mirrors John 1:3 – “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum est nihil quod factum est.” Both express that everything that exists does so through the one principle.

The emphasis on “unum” (one) and identity recalls Deut 6:4 “Dominus Deus noster, Dominus unus est,” the biblical affirmation of the unity of God, which Anselm invokes in his discussion of a single good versus many.

Monologion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Si illa summa natura tot bona est… necesse est ut illa omnia non plura sed unum sint
Monologion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that all goodness ultimately rests in one source echoes Psalm 145:13 “Domini est terra et plenitudo eius, mundus et omnes qui habitant in eo,” portraying God as the sole source of all good.

Monologion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Ex quo igitur haec tam simplex natura creatrix ...
Monologion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s opening question about the “simple nature creator” echoes Genesis 1:1 “In principio creavit Deus caelum et terram”, invoking the biblical account of God as the ultimate creator.

Monologion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: sine principio et sine fine est
Monologion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The description of God as “without beginning and without end” parallels Psalm 90:2, which declares God’s eternity “aeternus … a saeculo et usque in saeculum”.

Monologion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nec per se nec ex se, nec per aliud nec ex alto, nec per nihil nec ex nihilo habet principium
Monologion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s denial that the supreme nature has a beginning or an end mirrors Revelation 1:8 “Ego sum Alpha et Omega, principium et finis”, which explicitly names God as the beginning and the end.
The claim that the highest nature “does not have an end” recalls Revelation 22:13 where Christ says “Ego sum Alpha et Omega, principium et finis”, stressing the absence of an ultimate limit.
Anselm’s description of the supreme nature as “immortal and incorruptible” reflects 1 Tim 6:16, which attributes “immortality” to God alone.
The phrase “supreme powerful and omnipotent” resonates with Revelation 19:6, which proclaims God’s omnipotence.

Monologion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: veritas ... antequam esset veritas; et erit veritas, postquam finita erit veritas
Monologion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s discussion of “truth” existing before and after itself evokes John 1:1 “In principio erat Verbum… et Verbum erat Deus”, linking the concept of eternal truth to the Logos.

Monologion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quomodo ergo non incepit ex nihilo
Monologion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s question about “ex nihilo” echoes the Genesis creation narrative where God brings the world into being from “nothing” (the earth was “inanis et vacua” before God’s word).

Monologion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summum bonum quod lucerna ueritatis quaesitum et inuentum est
Monologion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The image of a “lucerna ueritatis” (lamp of truth) recalls John 8:12 where Jesus declares, “Ego sum lux mundi,” the light of the world, a metaphor for truth.
The motif of “nihil” (nothing) as a teacher of flight loosely parallels Psalm 115:5’s description of the “inanis” (void) that cannot save, suggesting that nothing cannot instruct or sustain.

Monologion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: creatrix haec natura ubique et in omnibus et per omnia sit
Monologion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that “this nature is creator everywhere and through all things” echoes the opening of Genesis 1:1, “In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth,” where God’s creative power is presented as universal and all‑encompassing.

The phrase “it neither began nor will cease to be” reflects Revelation 1:8, where Christ declares, “I am the Alpha and the Omega, the beginning and the end,” affirming eternal existence without beginning or end.

Monologion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nullum bonum nec penitus aliquid est sine ea
Monologion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s assertion that nothing good or anything at all exists apart from the supreme nature parallels Acts 17:28, “In Him we live and move and have our being,” which teaches that all existence depends on God.

Monologion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summa essentia aut ubique et semper est
Monologion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that the highest essence is everywhere and always mirrors Hebrews 13:8, “Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever,” emphasizing unchanging, omnipresent reality.
Anselm’s statement “nothing exists without it” rephrases John 1:3, “All things were made through Him, and without Him nothing was made,” expressing the dependence of all being on the divine.

Monologion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ubi et quando ipsa non est, ibi et tunc penitus nulla est essentia, quia sine ea nihil est
Monologion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The argument that where the supreme nature is absent, nothing can be, resonates with Psalm 139:7‑10, which asks where one can flee from God’s presence, implying that without God there is no place of existence.

Monologion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: aut tote est in omni loco uel tempore
Monologion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase mirrors the Vulgate Psalm 139:2 – “Scivi quod non est absconditum a te, quod in omni loco” – which affirms God’s presence everywhere; Anselm re‑words it in his logical discussion of omnipresence.

Monologion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quod si ita est, aut tote est in omni loco uel tempore… Non igitur partim est ubique et semper.
Monologion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage’s concern with “being everywhere and always” echoes Psalm 139:7‑8 (Vulgate: “Ubi ibo a spiritu tuo? et ubi fugiam a facie tua? Monologion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quid est quod totum est in aliquo loco, nihil eius est quod non sit in ipso loco.
Monologion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s logical claim that a thing wholly present in one place cannot be elsewhere reflects Acts 17:28 (“In ipso enim vivimus, et movemur, et sumus”), which states that God is present in all places and all times.

Monologion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam cum 'ibi' et 'ubi' localia verba sint, non tamen locali circumscriptione aut anima continet aliquid, aut intellectus vel rationalitas continentur.
Monologion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s discussion of the limits of local words (ubi, ibi) echoes Psalm 139:7‑10, where the psalmist asks where he can go that God’s spirit is not present, emphasizing God’s ubiquity beyond any local designation.

Monologion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summa natura secundum rei veritatem aptius dicitur esse ubique secundum hanc significationem, ut intelligatur esse in omnibus quae sunt
Monologion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that the highest nature exists ‘ubique’ (everywhere) and that all things exist in it parallels Colossians 1:17 – “He is before all things, and in Him all things hold together.”

Monologion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ut una eademque perfecte tota simul sit in singulis

Monologion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase mirrors 1 Tim 1,17 Vulgate “qui non habet initium, nec finem”, expressing God’s eternity as without beginning or end.

Monologion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nulli rerum creatarum ... de nihilo factae sunt
Monologion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The reference to created things that “came from nothing” evokes the Genesis creation narrative (Gen 1,1) and the theological doctrine of creation ex nihilo, though no exact wording is shared.

Monologion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: de summe incommutabili natura nihil potest dici, unde mutabilis possit intelligi
Monologion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the highest nature is immutable echoes Malachi 3:6 “Ego Dominus, non mutabor” (“I the LORD do not change”), a biblical affirmation of God’s unchangeability.

Monologion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sicut ergo semper sibi est omni modo eadem substantialiter, ita numquam est a se diuersa ullo modo vel accidentaliter.
Monologion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The insistence on absolute unity and unchangeability of the supreme nature parallels Deuteronomy 6:4 “Non est alius Deus praeter me” (“There is no other God besides me”), which stresses the singular, unvarying nature of God.

Monologion:26:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: de nihilo facit omne aliud esse

Monologion:27:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et ex his spiritus dignior est quam corpus
Monologion:27:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the spirit is “more noble” than the body echoes Matthew 26:41, where Jesus urges the disciples to watch that their spirit not be tempted, contrasting spirit with flesh.

Monologion:27:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nec partibus est compositus, nec ullis differentiis uel accidentibus intelligi potest esse mutabilis
Monologion:27:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The description of the spirit as indivisible and not composed of parts parallels 1 Cor 12:4’s statement that there are many gifts but “the same Spirit,” suggesting a unity of the Spirit that cannot be divided.

Monologion:28:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non est quod aliquando fuit aut non erit
Monologion:28:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the spirit “is not that which at some time was or will be” echoes Hebrews 13:8 (“Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and forever”), a biblical affirmation of divine immutability.

Monologion:28:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: fuit vel erit sed simpliciter est
Monologion:28:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The wording “was or will be, but simply is” parallels the divine self‑identification in Exodus 3:14 (“I am who I am”), stressing a simple, self‑existent being.

Monologion:28:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: per illum, qui solus absolute est, de nihilo aliquid facta sunt
Monologion:28:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s statement that all things were made “by Him, who alone is absolute, out of nothing” re‑phrases John 1:3 (“All things were made by Him; without Him was not anything made that was made”).

Monologion:28:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: creata non sunt; nec tamen omnino non: sunt
Monologion:28:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The assertion that “the created things are not non‑existent, yet they are not wholly non‑existent” paraphrases the opening of Genesis 1:1 (“In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth”), affirming the reality of creation by God.

Monologion:29:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Si enim ille nihil fecit nisi per seipsum, et quidquid ab eo factum est per illam est factum
Monologion:29:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm re‑words the Vulgate formula “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum est nihil quod factum est,” expressing that nothing is done apart from the supreme spirit itself.

Monologion:29:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summum spiritum ... locutio ... quod est sua intelligentia, qua cuncta intelligit
Monologion:29:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s identification of the spirit’s “locutio” (speech/Word) with its intelligence recalls the prologue’s identification of the Logos: “In principio erat Verbum… et Verbum erat apud Deum.”
The heading “UNUS SPIRITUS” and the discussion of a single, indivisible spirit reflect the Pauline affirmation that “Spiritus unum est” despite the diversity of gifts.

Monologion:30:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Non igitur constat pluribus uerbis sed est unum verbum per quod facta sunt omnia.
Monologion:30:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm re‑states the Johannine claim that the Logos (the Word) is the one through which all things were made (John 1:1‑3).

Monologion:30:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ut non sint duo sed unus spiritus
Monologion:30:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The emphasis on a single spirit reflects the biblical theme of divine unity expressed in Deut 6:4 (“The LORD our God, the LORD is one”).

Monologion:31:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quid igitur tenendum est de verbo, quo dicuntur et per quod facta sunt omnia?
Monologion:31:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase mirrors John 1:3 (Vulgate: “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum est nihil quod factum est”), re‑phrasing the biblical claim that all things were made through the Word.

Monologion:31:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: similitudes et imagines sunt rerum quarum verba sunt;
Monologion:31:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The discussion of “similitudo” and “imago” echoes Genesis 1:27 where humanity is created “ad imaginem” (in the image) of God, linking the philosophical notion of likeness to the biblical concept of image.

Monologion:31:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: verbum summae veritatis, quod et ipsum est summa veritas
Monologion:31:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s identification of the Word with the highest truth reflects John 14:6 (“Ego sum via et veritas et vita”), where Christ declares Himself to be truth; the passage draws on that theological theme without quoting directly.

Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: si aeterne se dicit, aeterne est uerbum eius apud ipsum.
Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the eternal self‑statement makes the Word itself eternal mirrors John 1:1 – “In principio erat Verbum… et Verbum erat apud Deum”. The passage uses the same concept of the Word’s co‑eternity with God.

Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summa sapientia, quae non est aliud quam idem spiritus
Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The identification of the highest wisdom with the spirit recalls Proverbs 8:22‑31, where Wisdom is personified as a divine spirit that existed before creation and is “the work of God”. Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: si nullo modo esset creatura, nequaquam esset uerbum illud, quod est summa et nullius indigens essentia
Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm argues that without creation there could be no Word, reflecting Genesis 1:3 where God creates by speaking: “Dixit Deus: Fiat lux”. Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nullum in illo uerbum esset, nihil apud se diceret
Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that without a word there is no declaration recalls Psalm 19:1 – “Caeli enarrant gloriam Dei, et firmamentum loquitur verbum Dei” – where the heavens themselves speak the Word of God. Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: aeternus ... memor est et intelligit se ad similitudinem mentis rationalis
Monologion:32:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of the eternal spirit remembering and knowing itself parallels Revelation 22:13 (“Ego sum Alpha et Omega, principium et finis”) which presents God as the eternal self‑knowing One. Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sed ecce quaerenti mihi de uerbo quo creator dicit omnia quae fecit, obtulit se uerbum quo seipsum dicit, qui omnia fecit.
Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reformulates John 1:1‑3 (In principio erat Verbum… omnia per ipsum facta sunt) by speaking of the "verbum" of the Creator that "dicit omnia quae fecit".

Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sed ecce quaerenti mihi de uerbo quo creator dicit omnia quae fecit, obtulit se uerbum quo seipsum dicit, qui omnia fecit.
Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage echoes Genesis 1:3 where God says "Et vidit Deus quod bonum esset" after creating, stressing that the Creator’s word brings all things into being.

Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam nulla ratione negari potest, cum mens rationalis seipsam cogitando intelligit, imaginem ipsius nasci in sua cogitatione; … cum cogito notum mihi hominem absentem, formatur acies cogitationis meae in talem imaginem eius, qualem illam per visum oculorum in memoriam attraxi.
Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s discussion of the mind forming an image of a person mirrors Genesis 1:26‑27 where humanity is created "ad imaginem et similitudinem" of God.

Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sed utique uerbum quo se dicit summa sapientia, conuenientissime dici potest uerbum eius secundum superiorem rationem, quia eius perfectam tenet similitudinem.
Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The identification of the "verbum" with "summam sapientiam" recalls Proverbs 8:22‑31 where Wisdom is personified as created before the world and associated with the divine word.

Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quod uerbum, licet de re tam singulariter eminenti proprie aliquid satis conuenienter dici non possit, non tamen inconuenienter sicut similitudo ita et imago et figura et caracter eius dici potest.
Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s treatment of the "verbum" as a substance that is not merely a likeness but the very essence reflects John 1:14’s claim that "Verbum caro factum est" – the Word became flesh, sharing the same substance as God.

Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam idem ipse qui his uerbis loquitur, eandem illis habet substantiam, et tamen uerbum non est.
Monologion:33:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that the Word (verbum) possesses the same substance as the Creator echoes Psalm 33:6 (per verbum Domini caeli facti sunt) which attributes creation to the divine word.

Monologion:34:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summus spiritus dicit seipsum, dicit omnia quae facta sunt

Monologion:34:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that created things are subject to corruption reflects Romans 8:20, which speaks of creation being “subjected to frustration” and awaiting redemption.

Monologion:34:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that in the supreme spirit lies the “first essence and the first truth of existence” echoes Colossians 1:16‑17, which says that all things were created through Him and that He is before all things.

Monologion:35:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Verbum eius consubstantiale illi est et perfecte simile, necessario consequitur, ut omnia quae sunt in illo, eadem et eodem modo sint in verbo eius.
Monologion:35:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of the Word (Verbum) as consubstantial with the divine and the claim that all things that exist in the divine are likewise in the Word mirrors John 1:1‑3 ("In principio erat Verbum… Omnia per ipsum facta sunt…").

Monologion:35:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: in illo est ipsa uita et veritas.

Monologion:35:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: in illo est ipsa uita et veritas.

Monologion:36:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: omnis creata substantia tanto uerius est in uerbo, id est in intelligentia creatoris, quam in seipsa
Monologion:36:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formula that created things are more truly in the “Word” (verbo) than in themselves echoes John 1:1‑2 (“In principio erat Verbum… et Verbum erat apud Deum”). Monologion:36:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nulli dubium creatas substantias multo aliter esse in seipsis quam in nostra scientia
Monologion:36:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that created substances are known more truly in God than in human knowledge parallels Psalm 19:1‑2, where the heavens and the firmament declare the glory of God, implying that creation testifies to the Creator’s truth beyond human comprehension.

Monologion:37:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summum spiritum per uerbum suum fecisse omnia
Monologion:37:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm re‑words John 1:3 (Vulgate: “per eum omnia facta sunt”) to assert that the supreme spirit created all things through the Word.

Monologion:37:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes John 1:1 (“In principio erat Verbum”) by insisting that the Word must be the highest essence, i.e., the first principle.

Monologion:37:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: una, quae sola creatrix et solum principium est omnium quae facta sunt
Monologion:37:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Reflects the creation motif of Genesis 1:1 (“In principio creavit Deus caelum et terram”) – the one (una) who alone is the creator and principle of all things.

Monologion:37:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Ipsa namque sola fecit non per aliud quam per se omnia ex nihilo
Monologion:37:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Paraphrases Colossians 1:16 (Vulgate: “per ipsum omnia facta sunt”) by stating that the Word alone made everything out of nothing.

Monologion:37:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summum spiritum per uerbum suum fecisse omnia
Monologion:37:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes Psalm 33:6 (“per verbum Domini caeli facti sunt”) – the idea that the heavens (and all creation) are made by the Word.

Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non tamen ambo simul sunt duae ueritates aut duo creatores
Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s insistence that there cannot be two truths or two creators reflects the Shema’s affirmation of the oneness of God: “Dominus Deus noster Dominus unus est”.

Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non sunt duo pares spiritus nec duo pares creatores
Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The denial of two equal spirits or creators parallels 1 Cor 8:6’s statement that there is one God and one Lord, emphasizing divine unity.

Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non sunt duo uerba nec duae imagines
Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that there are not two words mirrors John’s singular “Verbum” (the Word) as the unique divine expression.

Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non sunt duo uerba nec duae imagines
Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The reference to “imagines” evokes Genesis 1:27’s declaration that humanity is created in the image of God, stressing the uniqueness of that image.

Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam ille cuius est verbum aut imago, nec imago nec verbum est
Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The formulation re‑works John 1:1’s identification of the Word with God, denying that the Word can be a separate entity apart from God.

Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam ille cuius est verbum aut imago, nec imago nec verbum est
Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The mention of “imago” recalls Genesis 1:26‑27’s creation of man in the image of God, here used to argue that the divine image is not a second, distinct reality.

Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Etenim proprium est unius esse ex altero, et proprium est alterius alterum esse ex illo
Monologion:38:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The mutual dependence expressed resembles John 10:30’s “Ego et Pater unum sumus”, suggesting a unity that precludes a true plurality.

Monologion:39:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase echoes John 1:1 where the Logos (Word) is identified as the divine principle, here rendered as “the word of the supreme spirit.”

Monologion:39:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: creator de creatore, summum de summo
Monologion:39:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The wording parallels John 1:3 “per ipsum facta sunt omnia” – all things were made by the Creator through the Creator, expressed by Anselm as “creator from creator, the highest from the highest.”

Monologion:39:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: perfectam eius quasi proles parentis teneat similitudinem
Monologion:39:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s image of the Word as a “perfect offspring of the parent” mirrors John 1:14’s claim that the Word became flesh, a true child of the Father, sharing the Father’s likeness.

Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Si ergo uerbum summi spiritus sic est omnino ex ipsius sola essentia, et sic singulariter est illi simile, ut nulla proles sic sit omnino ex sola parentis essentia, aut sic similis parenti
Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of the "verbum summi spiritus" as existing wholly from the essence of the supreme spirit mirrors John 1:1‑3, where the Word is identified with God’s very being and all things are made through Him.

Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quodsi conuenientissime dicitur nasci, et tam simile est illi de quo nascitur: cur aestimetur simile quasi proles parenti
Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage’s emphasis on the offspring being “simile quasi proles parenti” echoes Genesis 1:26‑27, where humanity is created “in our image, after our likeness.”

Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nulla sic gignit, ut omnino nullius indigens sola per se ad gignendam prolem sufficiat
Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that no offspring can be generated solely from the parent’s essence reflects Romans 8:29’s theme of being “conformed to the image of His Son,” i.e., the necessity of a divine source for true likeness.

Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nulla sic gignitur, ut nulla admixta dissimilitudine omnimodam similitudinem parentis exhibeat
Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The concern that the offspring must display the full similarity of the parent without any dissimilarity parallels Psalm 8:4‑5, which marvels at humanity’s likeness to God despite being created a little lower than the angels.

Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quapropter illius est proprium uerissimum esse parentem, istius uero uerissimam esse prolem.
Monologion:40:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The statement that the parent is the truest parent and the offspring the truest child reflects John 14:9, where Jesus says, “He that hath seen me hath seen the Father,” linking perfect identity between Father and Son.

Monologion:41:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summi spiritus est uerissime gignere, et uerbi eius uerissime gigni
Monologion:41:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the Trinitarian doctrine that the Father (here expressed as the "summus spiritus") begets the Son, the "Verbum" (Word), as articulated in John 1:1‑3 ("In principio erat Verbum… et Verbum erat apud Deum…").
Paraphrases John 4:24 "Deus est spiritus" (God is spirit), applying the concept to the "summus spiritus" that truly begets.

Monologion:42:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam si idcirco conuenienter est ille pater et proles eius filius, quia uterque est spiritus
Monologion:42:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that both father and son are “spiritus” echoes Genesis 1:27 where man is created “in the image of God” and “male and female He created them,” a foundational biblical statement about the spiritual nature of humanity.

Monologion:42:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Verissimum igitur est summum spiritum patrem esse prolis suae.
Monologion:42:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The emphasis on the “summum spiritui patrem” reflects the Psalmist’s declaration “Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten thee,” highlighting the father‑son relationship as a divine reality.

Monologion:42:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sicut igitur proprium est illius uerissime gignere, istius vero gigni
Monologion:42:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formulation that it is proper for the “father” to generate the “son” mirrors the biblical command “Be fruitful and multiply” (Gen 1:28), a direct scriptural model for parent‑child generation.

The pairing of “veritas” (truth) and “sapientia” (wisdom) recalls Proverbs 8:22‑31 where Wisdom is personified as a primordial being existing before creation, a theme Anselm draws on in discussing the nature of the divine spirit.

Monologion:42:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quod si filius semper similior est patri quam filia, nihil autem similius est alteri quam summo patri proles sua
Monologion:42:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that the Son is always more like the Father than the daughter is reminiscent of John 5:19 where Jesus says, “the Son can do nothing of his own accord, but only what he sees the Father doing,” underscoring the intimate likeness between Father and Son.

Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam sic est alius pater, alius filius, ut cum ambos dixerim, uideam me duos dixisse; et sic est idipsum, quod est et pater et filius, ut non intelligam quid duos dixerim. ... non sunt duo patres aut duo filii sed unus pater et unus filius
Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the Father and the Son are not two distinct persons but one mirrors John 10:30 “Ego et Pater unum sumus” (I and the Father are one).

Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Ecce enim, cum sic impossibile sit eundem esse eum qui gignit et eum qui gignitur, atque eundem esse parentem et prolem, ut necesse sit alium esse genitorem, alium genitum, et alium esse patrem, alium filium
Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The contrast between “qui gignit” (the one who begets) and “qui gignitur” (the one who is begotten) echoes the prologue of John 1:1‑3, where the Logos is both “in principio erat” and “genitus” (the Word that was with God and was God).

Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: sic tamen idem esse illum qui gignit et illum qui gignitur, necnon parentem et prolem
Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formula that the begetter and the begotten are the same person reflects John 14:9 “Qui me videt, videt Patrem” (Whoever has seen me has seen the Father).

Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam sic est alius pater, alius filius, ... non sunt duo patres aut duo filii sed unus pater et unus filius, ... ita non sunt duo sed unum spiritus
Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The insistence on a single Father, a single Son, and a single Spirit parallels the Shema’s declaration of the oneness of God: “Dominus Deus noster, Dominus unus est.”

Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ut non sunt duo sed unum spiritus, quamuis et singuli patris et singuli filii sit perfectum esse spiritum
Monologion:43:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s statement that there is one Spirit, though both Father and Son are perfect spirits, resonates with the Trinitarian baptismal formula in Matthew 28:19, which names the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit together.

Monologion:44:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: "Sicut enim pater habet ... vitam in se­metipso", "ita" gignendo "dat filio habere" ... "uitam in semetipso"
Monologion:44:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reproduces the Vulgate wording of John 5:26 (Sicut Pater habet vitam in seipso, ita et Filius habet vitam in seipso) almost verbatim.

Monologion:44:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ut non per alienam sed per suam essentiam sit, per suam sapientiam sapiat, per suam uitam uiuat
Monologion:44:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The clause expands the John 5:26 quotation, restating the idea that the Son possesses life, essence and wisdom in himself, not from another source.

Monologion:44:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nequaquam enim repugnant, ut filius ... per se subsistat et de patre habeas esse … Non igitur sic intelligi potest quod pater filii aut filius patris sit essentia, quasi alter non possit subsistere per se sed per alterum
Monologion:44:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage echoes John 10:30 (Ego et Pater unum sumus) by arguing that the Son can subsist by himself while still being from the Father, stressing a unity of essence rather than a contradiction.

Monologion:44:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quare non repugnat filium et subsistere per se et esse de patre, quia hoc ipsum, id est per seipsum posse subsistere, necesse est ilium habere ex patre.
Monologion:44:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The reasoning mirrors John 5:19 (Pater non videt quisquam, nisi Pater, qui misit me; et qui me misit, ipse est) which teaches that the Son’s activity is inseparable from the Father’s.

Monologion:45:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: filio patris uirtus et sapientia seu ueritas, et iustitia
Monologion:45:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s list of “virtus (power) and sapientia (wisdom) … ueritas (truth) and iustitia (justice)” mirrors Paul’s description of the Son as “the power of God and the wisdom of God” (1 Cor 1:24).
The claim that the Son is the very essence of the Father echoes Jesus’ statement “I and the Father are one” (John 10:30).

Monologion:45:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: filio patris uirtus et sapientia seu ueritas
Monologion:45:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s identification of the Son with “virtus, sapientia, ueritas” recalls the prologue of John where the Word (Verbum) is identified with God and is the source of truth (John 1:1‑3).

Monologion:45:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: filius est essentia patris, quod est: filius est non differens essentia de patris essentia
Monologion:45:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that the Son shares the Father’s essence and that “all things were created through Him” parallels Colossians 1:15‑17, which presents Christ as the image of the invisible God and the source of all creation.

Monologion:45:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: filio patris uirtus et sapientia seu ueritas
Monologion:45:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The mention of “ueritas” (truth) for the Son evokes Jesus’ claim “I am the truth” in John 14:6, though the wording is not explicit.

Monologion:46:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formula mirrors John 1:1‑14 where the Son is identified as the true “Verbum” (Word) of God.

Monologion:46:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: veritas quoque patris aptissime dici potest filius
Monologion:46:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes John 14:9 (“He that hath seen me hath seen the Father”), expressing that the Son perfectly conveys the Father’s truth.

Monologion:46:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: intelligit et cognoscit et scit et sapit patrem
Monologion:46:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Resembles 1 John 5:20’s claim that the Son “has given us understanding,” linking the Son’s knowledge with the Father’s.

Monologion:46:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: perfectam intelligentiam ... cognitiōnem ... sapientiam ... quae ipsam patris essentiam intelligit
Monologion:46:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Reflects Colossians 1:15‑17, which describe the Son as the exact representation of the Father’s substance and the fullness of His wisdom.

Monologion:46:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: perfectam intelligentiam ... sapientiam ... quae ipsam patris essentiam intelligit
Monologion:46:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the personified Wisdom of Proverbs 8:22‑31, where Wisdom (often identified with the Son) is the perfect intelligence of the Father.

Monologion:47:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: si ipsa substantia patris est intelligentia et scientia et sapientia et ueritas
Monologion:47:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of the Father’s substance as intelligence, knowledge, wisdom and truth mirrors the prologue of John (1:1‑3) where the Logos (the Word) is presented as the source of all being and truth.

Monologion:47:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: sicut filius est intelligentia et scientia et sapientia et ueritas paternae substantiae
Monologion:47:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that the Son shares exactly the same attributes as the Father echoes John 10:30 (“I and the Father are one”) and the Johannine theme of the Son as the perfect image of the Father.
Anselm’s pairing of wisdom (sapientia) and truth (ueritas) reflects the personified Wisdom of Proverbs 8:22‑31, which is described as existing before creation and as a divine attribute.
The coupling of knowledge (scientia) and wisdom (sapientia) in the passage parallels Colossians 2:3, where in Christ are hidden “all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge.”
Anselm’s emphasis on truth (ueritas) as an essential attribute of both Father and Son resonates with Jesus’ self‑identification as “the truth” in John 14:6.

Monologion:48:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quoniam de memoria nasci verbum uidetur
Monologion:48:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the Word (verbum) is generated from memory echoes John 1:1‑3, where the Logos is presented as eternally existing with the Father and becoming flesh; the passage treats the Son as the intelligible offspring of the Father’s memory.

The language of “wisdom of the father” parallels Proverbs 8:22‑31, where Wisdom is personified as a creation of God, “the Lord created me at the beginning… before the world existed,” linking divine wisdom to the Father’s creative act.

Monologion:48:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: pater uero de nullo nata memoria
Monologion:48:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s statement that the Father’s memory is “born from nothing” reflects the doctrine of creation ex nihilo found in Genesis 1:1, “In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.”
The phrase “ultimate wisdom” recalls 1 Cor 1:30, which calls God “the wisdom of God,” though Anselm does not quote the verse directly.

Monologion:49:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nihil delectabilius in illis contemplandum inuenio quam mutui amoris affectum
Monologion:49:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that nothing is more delightful than mutual love echoes John 15:13 – “Maiorem autem caritatem nemo habet quam ut animam suam ponat pro amicis suis,” the biblical statement that the greatest love is self‑sacrifice for a friend.
The emphasis on a reciprocal love (“love one another”) reflects the central theme of 1 John 4:7‑8, where the author exhorts believers to “habete caritatem invicem” because love originates from God.
Anselz’s phrase that the supreme spirit “remembers himself” parallels Deuteronomy 5:15’s command “Memor esto quod non est Deus alius,” a reminder of God’s self‑knowledge and covenantal remembrance.

Monologion:49:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summus spiritus se amare, sicut sui meminit et se intelligit
Monologion:49:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The notion that the highest spirit loves itself mirrors the biblical declaration “Deus caritas est” (1 John 4:8), which identifies God Himself as the source and embodiment of love.

Monologion:50:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nulla enim res amatur sine eius memoria aut intelligentia
Monologion:50:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that nothing is loved apart from the memory and intellect of the beloved echoes the biblical teaching that God is love (Deus caritas est) and that love is inseparable from the knowledge of the beloved.

Monologion:50:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Patet igitur amorem summi spiritus ex eo procedere, quia sui memor est et se intelligit
Monologion:50:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage that the Holy Spirit’s love proceeds from his self‑memory and self‑understanding parallels John 15:13’s definition of love as self‑sacrifice, a love that flows from the Father through the Son to the Spirit.

Monologion:50:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quod si in memoria summi spiritus intelligitur pater, in intelligentia filius
Monologion:50:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formula that the Father is known in the Spirit’s memory and the Son in the Spirit’s intellect reflects the prologue of John (1:1‑3) where the Logos (the Son) is identified with God’s eternal thought and word.

Monologion:50:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: a patre pariter et filio summi spiritus amor procedit
Monologion:50:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The statement that love proceeds equally from the Father and the Son to the Holy Spirit mirrors the Trinitarian benediction of 2 Cor 13:14, which links the Father’s grace, the Son’s love, and the Spirit’s communion.

Monologion:51:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: singulus pater est summus spiritus, et singulus filius summus spiritus, et ambo simul unus spiritus
Monologion:51:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s statement that the Father and the Son are each the supreme spirit and together one spirit echoes John 10:30 where Jesus says “ego et Pater unum sumus” (I and the Father are one).

Monologion:51:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: amat se pater, amat se filius, et alter alterum
Monologion:51:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The mutual love of the Father and the Son mirrors John 17:21‑24, in which Jesus prays that the Father and the Son may be one and that the believers may share that same unity of love.
Anselm’s claim that each (Father and Son) must love himself and the other reflects the command in John 13:34‑35: “Mandatum novum do vobis, ut diligatis invicem.”

Monologion:51:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: in patre, et quod in filio
Monologion:51:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The pairing of “pater” and “filius” together with “spiritus” recalls the Trinitarian baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19, “in nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti.”

Monologion:51:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: idipsum est quod amat uel amatur in patre, et quod in filio
Monologion:51:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that the same love exists in the Father and in the Son reflects 1 John 4:8 (“Deus caritas est”) and the surrounding verses which speak of love originating from God and being manifested in the Father and the Son.

Monologion:52:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quantus ergo est amor iste summi spiritus
Monologion:52:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s question about the magnitude of the Spirit’s love echoes the biblical affirmation “Deus caritas est” (God is love), which frames love as an essential attribute of the divine.

Anselm’s statement that the love is “as great as He is” resonates with Psalm 145:3, “Magnus est Dominus, et laudabilis nimis,” which emphasizes the incomparably great nature of God.

Monologion:52:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quanta est eius essentia, quod aliter esse non potest
Monologion:52:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that the Spirit’s essence cannot be otherwise mirrors Isaiah 45:5’s declaration of God’s exclusive, unchangeable existence: “Ego sum Dominus, et non est alius.”

Monologion:52:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: si tantum se diligit, quantum sui meminit et se intelligit
Monologion:52:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s link between self‑love, remembrance, and understanding reflects Romans 5:5, where love of God is described as being poured into hearts through the Holy Spirit, suggesting that divine love involves self‑knowledge and presence.

Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: IPSE CUM PATRE ET FILIO UNUS SPIRITUS.
Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The Trinitarian formula of the Nicene Creed echoes Matthew 28:19, where Jesus commands baptism "in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit".

Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Denique si nulla umquam creatura, id est si nihi1 umquam aliud esset quam summus spiritus pater et filius: nihilominus seipsos et inuicem pater et filius diligerent.
Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The statement that the Father and the Son love each other reflects 1 John 4:8, "Deus caritas est" (God is love), and the broader Johannine theme that love is the essential nature of God.

Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Est igitur idem amor summa sapientia, summa ueritas, summum bonum
Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The triad of "sapientia, ueritas, bonum" parallels 1 Cor 1:24, which calls Christ "the wisdom of God" and, by extension, the truth and the good of God.

Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Est igitur idem amor summa sapientia, summa ueritas, summum bonum
Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The phrase "summa ueritas" recalls Jesus' claim in John 14:6, "Ego sum via, et veritas, et vita" (I am the way, the truth, and the life).

Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summe essentiae plures esse non possunt
Monologion:53:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The assertion that there cannot be more than one supreme essence echoes Deuteronomy 6:4, "Shema Yisrael… Ha‑Elohim echad" (The LORD is one).

Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et simul pater et filius non duo sed unus spiritus
Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the Father and the Son are “not two but one spirit” echoes John 10:30 where Jesus says, “Ego et Pater unum sumus” (I and the Father are one). Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam non ex eo procedit in quo plures sunt pater et filius sed ex eo in quo unum sunt
Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage stresses that love proceeds from the unity of Father and Son, not from a plurality of relations, recalling John 17:21 where Jesus prays that “they may all be one” (ut omnes unum sint). Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: unus a patre procedens, alter a filio; an unus non totus ab uno procedens sed partim a patre, partim a filio
Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The discussion of a single love that may be divided between Father and Son reflects the Johannine theme “Deus caritas est” (God is love) and the idea that love originates from God (the Father) and is expressed through the Son (1 John 4:8). Anselm is developing the same scriptural motif without quoting it.

Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et a singulo patre manat totus amor summi spiritus, et a singulo filio totus
Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formula that the whole love of the supreme spirit flows from the Father and likewise from the Son parallels John 14:9, where Jesus says, “Whoever has seen me has seen the Father,” indicating that the Son fully reveals the Father’s love. The connection is thematic rather than a direct quotation.

Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: simul a patre et filio non duo toti sed unus idemque totus
Monologion:54:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The emphasis on the Father and Son acting together as a single source of love anticipates the Trinitarian baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19, which mentions the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit as a unified divine reality. Anselm’s language reflects this scriptural conception of divine unity.

Monologion:55:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase “parentis imaginem” echoes Genesis 1:26 where God creates man “ad imaginem et similitudinem nostra”, i.e., in the image of the parent (God).

Monologion:55:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: verbum mox consideratur, se prolem eius esse a quo est
Monologion:55:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The discussion of the “verbum” (Word) that is “a quo est” (from whom it is) parallels John 1:1‑3 where the Logos is “in principio erat Verbum… et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum”.

Monologion:55:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nullatenus aliter a patre procedit quam a filio
Monologion:55:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that love proceeds from the Father and the Son in the same way reflects John 15:26 where the Holy Spirit is sent “a Patre” in the name of the Son, indicating a shared origin.

Monologion:55:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ut duo aliqua sint, quae singula perfectam … erunt duo in carne una
Monologion:55:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage’s image of two entities sharing a single nature (“ut duo … erunt duo in carne una”) resonates with Genesis 2:24’s statement that a man and woman “erunt duo in carne una”.

Monologion:55:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nulla veritas patitur ut dissimili uocabulo ad illum pater et filius referantur
Monologion:55:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The insistence that truth cannot tolerate a “dissimili uocabulo” for the Father and Son recalls John 8:32 “et cognoscetis veritatem, et veritas vos liberabit”, emphasizing the unity of truth in the divine persons.

Monologion:56:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: solus ille cuius verbum est genitor et ingenitus
Monologion:56:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes John 1:1‑3 where the Logos (Verbum) is described as being with God, as God, and as uncreated (ingenitus). Anselm mirrors the language of “Verbum” and its divine origin.

Monologion:56:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: solum autem verbum genitum, quia solum filius et proles est
Monologion:56:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Paraphrases John 3:16’s reference to the “only begotten Son” (unigenitus filius), contrasting the begotten Word with love, which Anselm says is neither begotten nor unbegotten.

Alludes to John 5:18 where the Jews accuse Jesus of making himself equal with God by calling God his Father, highlighting the exclusive paternal identity that Anselm attributes to the divine source of love.

Monologion:56:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: amor ... nec filius est nec proles est
Monologion:56:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Reflects 1 John 4:8 “God is love,” emphasizing that love is not a created offspring (filius or proles) but an essential, ungenerated attribute of God.
Resonates with Psalm 2:7 “I will be a father to the son,” suggesting that love, like the divine sonship, is not derived from any other source.

Monologion:57:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quod si dici potest: sicut uerbum summae essentiae filius est eius
Monologion:57:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm likens the Son to the "Verbum" (Word) of John 1:1‑3, where the Word is described as being with God and being God, i.e. the sum of divine essence.

Monologion:57:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quoniam autem idem amor singulus est summa essentia sicut pater et filius
Monologion:57:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the biblical affirmation "Deus caritas est" (God is love) found in 1 John 4:8, presenting love as the single, supreme essence shared by Father and Son.

Monologion:57:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et quod idem possit dici spiritus patris et filii
Monologion:57:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Paraphrases John 15:26, where the Holy Spirit is sent by the Father in the name of the Son, suggesting that the Spirit can be spoken of as belonging to both the Father and the Son.

Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: filius est substantia et sapientia et uirtus patris
Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the Son shares the Father’s substance, wisdom and virtue echoes John 1:1 (“In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum”), which presents the Son (the Logos) as identical in essence with God.

Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: filius est substantia et sapientia et uirtus patris
Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Hebrews 1:3 describes the Son as “the radiance of God’s glory and the exact imprint of his nature,” a formulation that parallels Anselm’s language of the Son as the Father’s substance, wisdom and virtue.
Anselm’s statement that the Spirit belongs to the Father and the Son reflects John 15:26, where the Holy Spirit is sent by the Father and testifies concerning the Son.
John 14:26 says the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father and will teach the disciples, reinforcing Anselm’s idea that the Spirit is essentially linked to both the Father and the Son.

Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: habet eandem essentiam et sapientiam et uirtutem quam pater
Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: 2 Peter 1:4 speaks of believers becoming “partakers of the divine nature,” a concept that resonates with Anselm’s claim that the Son (and Spirit) share the same essence, wisdom and virtue as the Father.

Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: habet eandem essentiam et sapientiam et uirtutem quam pater
Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Colossians 1:15 calls the Son “the image of the invisible God,” suggesting a sharing of divine essence and attributes, which parallels Anselm’s formulation.

Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: utriusque spiritus intelligi essentia uel sapientia uel uirtus patris et filii
Monologion:58:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: John 14:9‑10 records Jesus saying, “Whoever has seen me has seen the Father,” indicating that the Son perfectly reveals the Father’s essence, a notion Anselm mirrors in describing the Spirit as sharing the Father’s and Son’s essence, wisdom and virtue.

Monologion:59:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: in patre et filio et utriusque spiritu
Monologion:59:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s tri‑adic formula mirrors the baptismal command “in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,” establishing the same three‑person unity of God.
The claim that the Father is wholly present in the Son echoes Jesus’ statement, “Whoever has seen me has seen the Father,” expressing the full identity of the Father in the Son.
Anselm’s assertion that the Son is in the Father reflects Jesus’ declaration, “I and the Father are one,” emphasizing mutual indwelling.
The phrase that the Spirit is in the same relationship with both Father and Son parallels the Gospel’s teaching that the Holy Spirit “proceeds from the Father and the Son.”
The idea that none of the three persons exceeds another recalls the Shema’s affirmation of the oneness of God: “The LORD our God, the LORD is one.”
Anselm’s emphasis on love as a defining attribute of the divine persons reflects the Johannine claim “God is love,” linking the Trinity’s mutual love to scriptural theology.

Monologion:60:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: pater ... filius ... spiritus ... ut nec pater indigeat filio aut communi spiritu, nec filius patre ... siue idem spiritus patre aut filio
Monologion:60:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The triadic formula of Father, Son and Holy Spirit mirrors the baptismal command “In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti” (Matt 28:19), expressing the same Trinitarian unity.
Identifying the Holy Spirit with love echoes the biblical declaration “Deus caritas est” – “God is love” (1 John 4:8).

Monologion:60:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: singulus quisque essentialiter est ... summa essentia ... unusquisque ...
Monologion:60:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The insistence that each person of the Trinity is “essentially one” reflects the Shema’s affirmation of the oneness of God: “Hear, O Israel: the LORD our God, the LORD is one” (Deut 6:4).

Monologion:60:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nec pater indigeat filio ... nec filius patre ... quasi pater per se meminisse solum possit, intelligere autem non nisi per filium, et amare non nisi per spiritum
Monologion:60:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that the Father, Son and Spirit are mutually dependent for memory, understanding and love parallels Jesus’ statement of mutual indwelling: “I and the Father are one” (John 10:30), which the Church has interpreted as a basis for the inter‑relations of the Trinity.

Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: unus tantum est in summa essentia pater, unus filius, unus spiritus
Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formulation of a single essence containing one Father, one Son and one Spirit mirrors the Trinitarian baptismal formula “in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit.”

Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: unus tantum est in summa essentia pater, unus filius, unus spiritus
Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The same tri‑adic language recalls Paul’s benediction “the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit,” expressing the unity of the three persons.

Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: filius sic est memoria et amor, quamodo est intelligentia
Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of the Son as “memory and love” echoes the biblical claim “God is love,” linking the divine attribute of love to the Son.

Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: pater ita est intelligentia et amor
Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The pairing of intelligence (wisdom) and love with the Father reflects Proverbs 2:6, where the Lord gives wisdom, a trait often associated with divine love in Scripture.

Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Spiritum non cogit esse patrem aut filium
Monologion:61:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s statement that the Spirit is not a father or son parallels John 14:26, which presents the Holy Spirit as a distinct person sent by the Father, not identified as Father or Son.

Monologion:62:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: pater et filius et eorum spiritus
Monologion:62:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase echoes the Trinitarian baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19 – “in nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti” – although he does not quote it verbatim.

Monologion:62:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: verbum … in summa essentia … gignere verbum …
Monologion:62:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The discussion of “verbum” (Word) as something that is generated (gignere) by the Father and the Son reflects the prologue of John 1:1‑3 (“In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum”) where the Word is identified with the divine essence.
