Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: pater et filius et eorum spiritus
Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s explicit mention of Father, Son and their Spirit echoes the Trinitarian baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19.

Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: verbum … imago et filius eius cuius est verbum
Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The repeated use of “verbum” (Word) together with “imago” (image) and “filius” (Son) paraphrases John 1:1‑14, where the Word is identified with God, is the image of the Father, and becomes flesh.

Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: una quippe sapientia est quae in illis dicit
Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that there is one wisdom speaking in the three persons reflects 1 Cor 1:24, which calls Christ “the wisdom of God.”
The insistence on the unity of the Father mirrors the Shema’s declaration of the oneness of God (Deut 6:4).
Anselm’s statement that there is one Son, not many, parallels Jesus’ claim “I and the Father are one” (John 10:30) which stresses the unity of the Son with the Father.
The description of the Son as the “image” (imago) of the Father and as the Word (verbum) follows Colossians 1:15, which calls Christ “the image of the invisible God.”

Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non imitatur nec ad eius similitudinem existit
Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the Son is not an imitation but the exact representation of the Father echoes Hebrews 1:3, which calls Christ “the exact imprint of his nature.”

Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summae sapientiae inest scire et intelligere
Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The equation of supreme wisdom with knowledge and understanding reflects Proverbs 2:6, where wisdom and understanding are said to come from the Lord.

Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non sunt plura quae dicuntur, cum unusquisque seipsum et alios duos dicit
Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage’s insistence that the three persons do not constitute three separate sayings resonates with the Trinitarian testimony of 1 John 5:7 (“the Father, the Word, and the Holy Spirit are three”).

Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ex eo cuius est verbum, ut et uera eius dici possit imago et uere filius eius sit
Monologion:63:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formula that the Word is generated from the one to whom the Word belongs and that the Son can be called the true image of that One parallels John 1:12, which speaks of those who receive the Word becoming children of God.

Monologion:64:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quid autem tam incomprehensibile, tam ineffabile, quam id quod super omnia est?
Monologion:64:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of God as “incomprehensible, ineffable, above all things” echoes Isaiah 55:8‑9 where the Lord declares that His thoughts and ways are far beyond human understanding.

Monologion:64:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quid autem tam incomprehensibile, tam ineffabile, quam id quod super omnia est?
Monologion:64:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The phrase also parallels Psalm 145:3 (“great is the LORD, and greatly to be praised; his greatness is unsearchable”), stressing the unsearchable greatness of God.

The rhetorical question about who can narrate God’s generation reflects John 1:1‑3, where the Logos is described as “the Word was in the beginning… all things were made through Him,” raising the mystery of divine generation.

Monologion:64:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: si superior consideratio rationabiliter comprehendit incomprehensibile esse
Monologion:64:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the “higher consideration rationally grasps the incomprehensible” mirrors Romans 11:33, which exclaims the depth of the riches, wisdom, and knowledge of God.

Monologion:64:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nullatenus tamen certitudinis eorum nutat soliditas
Monologion:64:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The statement that the certainty of these truths “does not shake” corresponds to Hebrews 11:1, defining faith as “the substance of things hoped for, the proof of things not seen.”

Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: summa essentia supra et extra omnem aliam naturam, ut si quando de illa dicitur aliquid uerbis, quae communia sunt aliis naturis, sensus nullatenus sit communis
Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of God’s essence as “above and beyond every other nature” echoes Psalm 145:3 (Vulgate: “Magnus Dominus, et laudabilis nimis, et magnitudinem eius non potest investigare”), which portrays God’s greatness as incomprehensible to human reason.

Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Saepe namque multa dicimus, quae proprie sicut sunt non exprimimus sed per aliud significamus… ut cum per aenigmata loquimur.
Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The reference to speaking “through riddles” (aenigmata) parallels Jesus’ use of parables (Greek: παραβολαί) in Matthew 13:34, where the Gospel notes that He spoke to the crowds in parables.

Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ut cum uultum alicuius consideramus in speculo.
Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s image of seeing a face in a mirror reflects 1 Cor 13:12 (Vulgate: “Nunc autem per speculum in tenebris videmus, sed facie ad faciem”), a biblical metaphor for the limited nature of human knowledge.

Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam nec nomen sapientiae mihi sufficit ostendere illud, per quod omnia facta sunt de nihilo…
Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that the name of wisdom is insufficient to denote the source of all things recalls Proverbs 8:22‑23 (Vulgate: “Dominus me creavit; antequam mundus fieret…”) where Wisdom is presented as a divine principle present before creation.

Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nec nomen essentiae mihi valet exprimere illud, quod per singularem altitudinem longe est supra omnia
Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of an “altitudinem longe est supra omnia” (a height far above all) resonates with Isaiah 57:15 (Vulgate: “Altissimus et sublimis ipse est”) which speaks of God as the Most High and Sublime.

Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quid ergo? An quodam modo inuentum est aliquid de incomprehensibili re…
Monologion:65:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The phrase “something found about the incomprehensible thing” loosely echoes 1 Tim 6:15 (Vulgate: “qui vivit in luce invisibilis”) which describes God as living in an invisible light beyond human comprehension.

Monologion:66:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quidquid enim inter creata constat illi esse similius
Monologion:66:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that whatever exists among created things is more similar to the Creator echoes Genesis 1:26‑27, where humanity is said to be made in the image and likeness of God.

Monologion:66:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: omnis essentia, in quantum est, in tantum sit summae similis essentiae
Monologion:66:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that every created essence, insofar as it exists, reflects the supreme essence parallels Romans 1:20, which teaches that God’s invisible qualities are clearly seen in what has been made.

Monologion:66:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sicut sola est mens rationalis inter omnes creaturas, quae ad eius investigationem assurgere valeat
Monologion:66:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of the rational mind as the unique rational creature among all creations recalls Psalm 8:4’s rhetorical question about the special status of man in the created order.

Monologion:66:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quid igitur apertius quam quia mens rationalis quanto studiosius ad se discendum intendit, tanto efficacius ad illius cognitionem ascendit
Monologion:66:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage paraphrases the wisdom motif of Proverbs 4:7 (“Wisdom is the principal thing; therefore get wisdom”), linking diligent self‑study with a higher knowledge of the Creator.

Monologion:67:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: in quo speculetur ut ita dicam imaginem eius, quam "facie ad faciem" uidere nequit.
Monologion:67:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reproduces the Pauline image of seeing “through a glass, darkly” and then “face to face” (Vulgate: “per speculum in tenebris videmus, sed tunc facie ad faciem”).

Monologion:67:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non uideo cur negetur esse in illa uera imago illius essentiae, quae per sui memoriam et intelligentiam et amorem in trinitate ineffabili consistet.
Monologion:67:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage speaks of a “true image of that essence,” echoing the biblical claim that humanity is created “in the image (imago) of God.”

Monologion:67:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nihil igitur aliud est inditum alicui creaturae, quod sic praefert imaginem creatoris.
Monologion:67:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that created beings are given a likeness that “prefers” the Creator’s image recalls Colossians 1:15’s description of Christ as “the image of the invisible God.”

Monologion:68:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: imaginem sibi per naturalem potentiam impressam per uoluntarium effectum exprimere
Monologion:68:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s reference to the creature bearing an “image” impressed by natural power echoes Genesis 1:27, where humanity is created in the image (imago) of God.

Monologion:68:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ut summam essentiam amet super omnia bona, sicut ipsa est summum bonum
Monologion:68:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage’s claim that the rational creature must love the supreme good mirrors the biblical command to love God with all one’s heart, soul, and strength (Deut 6:5; cf. Mark 12:30).

Monologion:68:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: discernere iustum a non iusto, verum a non vero, bonum a non bono
Monologion:68:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s emphasis on the rational ability to distinguish right from wrong, true from false, good from evil reflects Deuteronomy 30:19’s exhortation to choose life and good, which presupposes such moral discernment.

Monologion:69:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the Shema command “Amabis Dominum Deum tuum” – to love the supreme being with all one’s heart, soul and strength.
Paraphrases the famous line “caritas numquam peribit” (love never fails), i.e., love without end.
Recalls Jesus’ promise “et nemo eripiet illos de manu mea” – no one can snatch away the life given by the Father.
Reflects the biblical portrait of God as the most good and all‑powerful (e.g., “Magnus est Dominus, et laudabilis nimis; et magnitudo eius infinita”).
Matches the Vulgate wording “Longam vitam dabit tibi, et ostendet tibi salutem.”

Monologion:69:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: qui est summe bonus et omnipotens, semper misere uiuat
Monologion:69:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the scriptural affirmation that “Deus est caritas” – God is love, the source of perfect, everlasting love.

Monologion:70:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Ut quod “nunc” uidet quasi “per speculum et in aenigmate, tunc” uideat “facie ad faciem”.
Monologion:70:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reproduces verbatim the Vulgate wording of 1 Cor 13:12 ("nunc per speculum in aenigmate videmus, tunc autem facie ad faciem").
The phrase echoes Psalm 145:17 where the Vulgate calls God “justus et iustus” (just and righteous), linking divine justice with supreme power.

Monologion:70:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam quis sic amet iustitiam, ueritatem, beatitudinem, incorruptibilitatem, ut iis frui non appetat?
Monologion:70:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s appeal to loving justice, truth, beatitude and incorruptibility reflects the Psalmist’s celebration of those who love the law of the Lord (Psalm 119:2).

Monologion:71:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase “eternal misery” echoes Matthew 25:46, where the Vulgate says “poenam aeternam” (eternal punishment) for the wicked.
The image of the lover rejoicing in an “eternal reward” parallels the servant’s “intra in gaudium domini tui” (enter into your master’s joy) as a reward for faithful service.
Anselm’s call that the soul should love the “summum bonum” (the supreme essence) reflects the Shema’s command to love the Lord with all one’s heart, soul, and strength.
The notion that contempt for God leads to “eternal misery” resembles 2 Thessalonians 1:9, where the Vulgate speaks of “perdam aeternam” (eternal destruction) for those who do not obey the gospel.

Monologion:72:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: id ad quod amandum creata est
Monologion:72:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that the soul was created for love echoes the Genesis creation narrative where God breathes the “spirit of life” into man, implying that the human being is created to love God.
The question of whether souls are mortal or immortal reflects Daniel 12:2’s dichotomy of those who “shall awake” (immortal) and those who “shall die” (mortal).
Anselm’s reference to “the souls of infants” parallels Jesus’ teaching that one must become “like a child” (puer) to enter the kingdom of heaven (Matt 18:3).

The assertion that all human souls are immortal recalls 1 Tim 6:16, which affirms that God alone “dwells in unapproachable light, whom no man has seen or can see,” and is the source of true immortality, a concept Anselm extends to every human soul.

Monologion:73:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Verum cum omne quod uiuit aut numquam aut aliquando sit uere securum ab omni molestia
Monologion:73:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Paraphrases Sirach 7:20, which declares that no human life is completely safe from danger or trouble.

Monologion:73:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nihilominus est necesse omnem humanam animam aut semper miseram esse aut aliquando uere beatum
Monologion:73:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the theme of Sirach 7:21‑22, which observes that human existence is marked by sorrow and occasional joy, i.e., a life that is at times miserable and at times truly blessed.

Monologion:74:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et ad idem ipsum bonum est omni homini toto corde, tote anima, tote mente amando et desiderando nitendum.
Monologion:74:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm echoes the Vulgate Shema (Deut 6:5) – “Diliges Dominum Deum tuum ex toto corde tuo, et ex tota anima tua, et ex omnibus cogitationibus tuis” – by substituting “mente” for “cogitationibus” and extending the command to the love of the highest good.

Monologion:75:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: si desperet quo intendit se posse pervenire
Monologion:75:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm contrasts the soul’s despair with its ability to reach its goal, echoing Romans 5:5 where hope (spes) is said not to be put to shame, implying that despair undermines the soul’s capacity to attain what it seeks.
The statement that hope is necessary for reaching (pertingendi) reflects Hebrews 6:19, which describes hope as an anchor for the soul, essential for attaining spiritual fulfillment.

Monologion:76:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Amare autem aut sperare non potest, quod non credit.
Monologion:76:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reformulates the definition of faith in Heb 11,1 ("faith is the substance of things hoped for, the proof of things not seen"), asserting that love or hope cannot exist without belief.

Monologion:76:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: tendere in illam … si quis tendendo ad illam peruenerit, non extra illam remanebit sed intra illam permanebit
Monologion:76:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The verb *tendere* (to stretch, to aim) recalls Psalm 42,1 where the soul “tends” toward God like a deer longs for water, expressing a yearning toward the supreme essence.

Monologion:76:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam non uidetur credere in illam siue qui credit quod ad tendendum in illam non pertinet, siue qui per hoc quod credit non ad illam tendit.
Monologion:76:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that one must “remain in” the divine (here expressed as staying within the supreme essence) echoes Jesus’ command in John 15,4: “Abide in me, and I in you.”

Monologion:76:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam si quis dicat se credere in illam, satis uidetur ostendere … et illa se credere quae ad hanc pertinent intentionem.
Monologion:76:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s triadic discussion of love, hope, and belief mirrors the Pauline triad of faith, hope, and love in 1 Cor 13,13, though he does not quote it directly.

Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Credendum igitur est pariter in patrem et filium et eorum spiritum
Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formula mirrors the Trinitarian baptismal command “in nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti,” substituting “in patrem et filium et eorum spiritum” for the Vulgate wording.

Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: simul pater et filius cum suo spiritu sunt una eademque summa essentia
Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that the Father, Son, and Spirit are “una eademque summa essentia” echoes John 10:30’s declaration “Ego et Pater unum sumus,” extending the unity to the Holy Spirit.

Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: simul pater et filius cum suo spiritu sunt una eademque summa essentia
Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The notion of a single divine essence shared by the three persons reflects the prologue’s description of the Word’s unity with God ("Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum").

Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: solus finis quem in omni cogitatu actuque suo per amorem debet intendere
Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s emphasis on love as the ultimate end of human thought parallels 1 John 4:8’s definition of God as love ("Deus caritas est").

Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: solus finis quem in omni cogitatu actuque suo per amorem debet intendere
Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The three‑fold formula of Father, Son, and Spirit as the single goal of the believer recalls the Trinitarian benediction “Gratia… caritas… communio Spiritus Sancti” in 2 Cor 13:14.

Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: sicut in illam tendere nisi credat illam nullus potest
Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The clause “nullus potest … credere” directly reflects Hebrews 11:6’s statement that “without faith it is impossible to please God.”

Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: sicut in illam tendere nisi credat illam nullus potest
Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that what is impossible for man is possible for God ("nullus potest") resonates with Mark 10:27’s contrast between human impossibility and divine possibility.

Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: ita illam credere nisi tendat in illam nulli prodest
Monologion:77:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The connection between seeking (tendere) and believing mirrors Romans 10:17’s formula that “faith comes by hearing,” suggesting that without the directed effort toward God, belief is unproductive.

Monologion:78:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: inutilis erit fides et quasi mortuum aliquid, nisi dilectione ualeat et uiuat.
Monologion:78:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s statement that faith is useless and “as if dead” without love mirrors the Vulgate James 2:17: “Sic et fides, si non habet opera, mortua est in semetipsis.” The structure and idea are the same, though Anselm replaces “works” with “love.”

Monologion:78:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quapropter, quantacumque certitudine credatur tanta res: inutilis erit fides …
Monologion:78:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The opening clause recalls James 2:14 (“Quid prodest, fratres mei, si quis dicat se habere fidem, et non habeat opera?”), presenting the problem of a faith that lacks the proper operative power. Anselm’s wording is not a verbatim quote but follows the same argumentative pattern.

Monologion:78:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quod summam iustitiam diligit, nihil iustum contemnere, nihil ualet iniustum admittere.
Monologion:78:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s insistence that love (dilectio) is essential for true justice echoes 1 Cor 13:2 (“et si habuero prophetias … et non habuerit charitatem, nihil sum”), where Paul declares that without love one is nothing. The theme that love gives value to all moral action is shared.

Monologion:78:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: caecus dicitur non tantum qui perdidit uisum sed qui cum debet habere non habet
Monologion:78:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage’s use of “caecus” (blind) to denote one who lacks what he ought to have recalls John 9:39, where Jesus says, “Quia videtis, non creditis.” Anselm’s metaphorical blindness is not a direct quotation but reflects the biblical motif of spiritual blindness.

Monologion:79:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: trinitatem propter patrem et filium et utriusque spiritum
Monologion:79:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm re‑states the baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19, where Christ commands baptism "in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit".

Monologion:79:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: unam quidem et unitatem propter unam essentiam
Monologion:79:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The emphasis on a single unity reflects the Shema’s declaration that the LORD is one ("Dominus Deus tuus unus est").
The opening exclamation "Ecce" recalls the Johannine cry "Ecce homo" ("Behold the man"), invoking the scriptural habit of presenting a truth plainly to all.
Anselm’s discussion of substance without accidents parallels Hebrews 1:3, which describes the Son as "substantia sua" (the very nature of God) unmediated by created qualities.

Monologion:80:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: omnia per summe bonam summeque sapientem omnipotentiam eius facta sunt et uigent
Monologion:80:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm re‑words the Vulgate wording of John 1:3 ("Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum non est nihil quod factum est") to stress that all things are made by the supreme good, wisdom and power of God.

Monologion:80:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: omnia per summe bonam summeque sapientem omnipotentiam eius facta sunt et uigent
Monologion:80:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The clause mirrors Colossians 1:16 ("per quem omnia facta sunt, quae in caelis et in terra sunt, visibiles et invisibiles"), echoing the idea that everything exists through God’s supreme goodness and wisdom.

Monologion:80:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: cum ille solus sit, per quem cuilibet et sine quo nulli bene est
Monologion:80:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrasing parallels John 1:3’s claim that without Him nothing was made that has been made, emphasizing God’s unique role as the source of all good.
The affirmation of a “sole God” echoes the Shema’s declaration “Dominus Deus noster, Dominus unus est” (Deut 6:4), stressing monotheistic exclusivity.
Anselm’s description of God as “ineffably three and one” reflects the Trinitarian baptismal formula of Matthew 28:19, which names the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit as a single divine reality.

Proslogion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Exact wording of the Vulgate Psalm 78:25 “Manducavit panem angelorum”.
Echoes the parable of the rich man who ate in abundance while Lazarus suffered hunger (Luke 16:19‑21).
Further development of the same Luke 16:19‑21 contrast between the rich man’s abundance and the poor’s need.

Proslogion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: "Ille feliciter tenebat et misere deseruit, nos infeliciter egemus"
Proslogion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Parallels the rich man’s selfishness and the poor man’s neglect in Luke 16:20‑21.

Proslogion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Domine, si hic non es, ubi te quaeram absentem? Si autem ubique es, cur non uideo praesentem?
Proslogion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Reflects Psalm 139:7‑10 which speak of God’s omnipresence – “Where can I flee from your spirit?”
Alludes to John 1:5 “the light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it”, portraying the divine light as inaccessible to human eyes.
The phrase “cor meum” evokes Psalm 51:10 “Create in me a clean heart, O God”.
Reference to “the sons of Adam” (Genesis 3:22) as a collective of fallen humanity.
Echoes Psalm 137:1 “By the rivers of Babylon we sat down and wept, when we remembered Zion.”

Proslogion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: "A iucunditate immortalitatis in amaritudinem et horrorem mortis"
Proslogion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Parallels Romans 6:23 “For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.”

Proslogion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: "Quid faciet altissime domine, quid faciet iste tuns longinquus exsul?"
Proslogion:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Resembles Psalm 13:1 “How long, O Lord, will you forget me?” – a plea concerning divine action toward the distant exile.
Paraphrases Psalm 69:1 “Save me, O God, for the waters have come up to my neck” where the psalmist seeks good and meets turmoil.
Echoes 2 Cor 4:17 “For our light and momentary troubles are achieving for us an eternal glory beyond all comparison.”
Alludes to 1 Tim 6:10 “For the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil.”

Proslogion:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: dixit insipiens in corde quo: non est deus
Proslogion:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reproduces the opening line of Psalm 14 (also Psalm 53) in the Vulgate: “Dixit insipiens in corde suo: Non est Deus.”

Proslogion:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quia es sicut credimus, et hoc es quod credimus
Proslogion:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The wording echoes Hebrews 11:1, where faith is defined as “substantia rerum sperandarum, argumentum rerum non visibilium,” i.e., belief in what is not seen.

Proslogion:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et quod intelligitur in intellectu eius est
Proslogion:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that what is understood exists in the intellect reflects the prologue of John 1:1 – “In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum,” linking existence with the divine Logos (the ultimate intelligible).

Proslogion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Cur itaque "dixit insipiens in corde quo: non est deus"
Proslogion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reproduces verbatim the Vulgate wording of Psalm 14:1 (also Psalm 53:1), which reads “Dixit insipiens in corde suo: Non est Deus.”

Proslogion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Solus igitur uerissime omnium, et ideo maxime omnium haloes esse
Proslogion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The phrase echoes the Shema’s declaration “Dominus Deus noster, Dominus unus est” (Deut 6:4), re‑expressed as “the one truly of all” and “the greatest of all.”

Proslogion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quod maior est quam quod non esse cogitari potest… quod conuenire non potest
Proslogion:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s notion of God as “the greatest being that can be thought” reflects the biblical theme of God’s supreme greatness found in Psalm 145:3 (“Magnus Dominus, et laudabilis nimis est”).

Proslogion:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase evokes Jeremiah 31:33 where God says He will write His law “in the heart” (in corde) of the people, suggesting a divine utterance that resides within the heart.

Proslogion:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Deus enim est id quo maioris cogitari non potest
Proslogion:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that God is “that by which a greater thing cannot be thought” parallels Psalm 145:3’s declaration of God’s greatness and infinite wisdom, emphasizing the incomparability of the divine.
Anselm’s expression of thanks to the “good Lord” reflects the psalmist’s call in Psalm 106:1 to give thanks to the Lord, who is good.

Proslogion:5:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that God created “all other things from nothing” echoes the opening of Genesis 1:1, where the Vulgate says “In principio creavit Deus caelum et terram” – the doctrine of creation ex nihilo.

Proslogion:5:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Tu es itaque iustus, uerax, beatus
Proslogion:5:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The triad of divine attributes (just, true, blessed) parallels Psalm 25:8, which in the Vulgate reads “Bonum est quod Dominus iustus, misericors, et misericordia eius in aeternum,” attributing righteousness and mercy to the Lord.

Proslogion:5:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Melius namque est esse iustum quam non iustum, beatum quam non beatum
Proslogion:5:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The comparative formula “Melius est … quam …” recalls Sirach 7:20, “Melius est timere Deum quam timere hominem,” employing the same rhetorical structure to rank moral goods.

Proslogion:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of God as the “highest spirit” echoes John 4:24 where the Vulgate says “Deus est spiritus”. Both stress God’s purely spiritual nature.
The attribute of omnipotence attributed to God reflects Psalm 147:5 “Magnus Dominus noster, et multum potens”, a classic biblical portrayal of God’s all‑powerful nature.
Anselm’s pairing of mercy with God recalls Psalm 103:8 “Misericors Dominus, et plenus misericordia”, which celebrates God’s merciful character.
The notion that God is impassible (unchanging) parallels Malachi 3:6 “Ego Dominus, non mutabor”, a biblical statement of God’s immutability.
Anselm’s emphasis on knowing (cognoscere) God as the highest form of perception mirrors John 17:3 “Haec est vita aeterna, ut cognoscant te solum verum Deum”.
The address “Domine” evokes the frequent biblical address to God, notably Psalm 23:1 “Dominus pastor meus”, establishing a familiar scriptural tone.

Proslogion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: omnipotens ... si omnia non poses? ... nihil potes per impotentiam, et nihil potest contra te.
Proslogion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s discussion of God’s ability to do all things and the impossibility of acting through impotence echoes Luke 1:37 – “Quia non est quod impossibile sit apud Deum” (“Nothing is impossible for God”).
The claim that nothing can be against God parallels Romans 8:31 – “Si Deus pro nobis, quis contra nos?” (“If God is for us, who can be against us?”).

Proslogion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Ergo domine deus, inde uerius es omnipotens, quia nihil potes per impotentiam, et nihil potest contra te.
Proslogion:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The prayer‑like address to the Lord, affirming His supreme power and that nothing opposes Him, reflects the tone of Psalm 115:1 – “Non nobis, Domine, non nobis, sed nomini tuo da gloriam” (a declaration of God’s exclusive greatness).

Proslogion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sed et misericors simul et impassibilis quomodo es?
Proslogion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Psalm 103:8 declares that the Lord is merciful (misericors) and gracious, a direct thematic parallel to Anselm’s juxtaposition of divine mercy with divine impassibility.

Proslogion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quomodo ergo es et non es misericors, domine
Proslogion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Luke 6:36 commands “Be merciful, as your Father is merciful,” echoing Anselm’s question about how God can be both merciful and not merciful.

Proslogion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Et misericors es igitur, quia miseros saluas et peccatoribus tuis parcis
Proslogion:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Psalm 86:5 praises God as “good and merciful,” resonating with Anselm’s claim that God’s mercy is shown in saving the miserable and sparing sinners.

Romans 9:15 speaks of God’s sovereign choice in dispensing mercy (“I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy”), reflecting Anselm’s idea that God is merciful according to a divine standard, not according to human expectation.
Numbers 23:19 states that God is not a man that He should change, a notion often linked to divine impassibility; Anselm’s use of “impassibilis” evokes this scriptural concept.

Proslogion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase mirrors Psalm 36:7 Vulgate – “Altitudo tua, Domine, super caelos… misericordia tua” – evoking the image of God’s lofty goodness and mercy.

Proslogion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Flumen misericordiae tuae… unde manat fluuius misericordiae tuae.
Proslogion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The metaphor of a flowing river of mercy echoes Psalm 36:7, where God’s mercy is praised as a precious thing, and the river‑image is a common biblical motif (cf. Psalm 46:5 “flumen… in corde meo”).

Proslogion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Parce per clementiam, ne ulciscaris per iustitiam!
Proslogion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s appeal to spare the wicked “by clemency, lest you avenge by justice” paraphrases Romans 12:19 Vulgate: “non vindicetis, sed date locum irae Dei,” urging restraint from vengeance.

Proslogion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Misericordia tua, quia summe iustus es…
Proslogion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The link Anselm draws between mercy and justice recalls James 2:13 Vulgate – “Misericordia triumphat iudicio” – though the wording is not a direct quotation.

Proslogion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: O altitudo bonitatis tuae, deus! et uidetur unde sis misericors, et non peruidetur.
Proslogion:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The description of God’s incomprehensible, lofty goodness and mercy reflects Psalm 86:15 Vulgate: “Tu autem, Domine, es Deus misericors et plenus gratia, longanimitas et multum benignus et verax.”

Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sed et iustum est, ut malos punias… et iustum est ut malis parcas?
Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s juxtaposition of justice (punishing the wicked) and mercy (sparing the wicked) echoes Micah 6:8, which commands the faithful to “do justice, love mercy, and walk humbly with your God.”

Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam parcendo malis ita iustus es secundum te et non secundum nos, sicut misericors es secundum nos et non secundum te.
Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The clause “sic misericors es” paraphrases Psalm 103:8, “Misericors et clemens est Dominus,” applying the divine attribute of mercy to the human judge Anselm describes.

Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam parcendo malis ita iustus es secundum te…
Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The tension between mercy and righteousness mirrors Psalm 85:10, “Misericordia et veritas conveniunt; justitia et pax se coniungunt,” where mercy and truth meet righteousness.

Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sic itaque sine repugnantia iuste punis et iuste parcis.
Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that it is just to punish the wicked without contradiction reflects Romans 12:19, “Vengeance is mine; I will repay, says the Lord,” which places divine justice beyond human partiality.

Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quoniam saluando nos quos iuste perderes…
Proslogion:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The phrase “saluando nos” loosely recalls Psalm 85:9, “Salvabit nos Dominus ex inimicis nostris,” invoking the idea of God’s saving action toward those he judges.

Proslogion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: IUSTUS DOMINUS IN OMNIBUS VIIS SUIS
Proslogion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reproduces verbatim the opening clause of Psalm 145:17 (Vulgate: “Justus Dominus in omnibus viis suis”), only differing in the classical u/v orthography.

Proslogion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: uniuersoe uiae domini misericordia et ueritas
Proslogion:11:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The phrase re‑expresses the second clause of Psalm 145:17 (“et misericordia eius in omnibus operibus eius”), substituting “universae uiae” for “omnibus operibus” and adding “veritas” as a thematic expansion.

Proslogion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Tu es igitur ipsa uita qua uiuis
Proslogion:12:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the Johannine formula “Ego sum via, veritas, et vita” (John 14:6), presenting the subject as the very life by which he lives.
Recalls the biblical theme that wisdom comes from the Lord (e.g., Prov 2:6 “Dominus dat sapientiam”), linking the subject’s understanding to divine wisdom.
Resonates with the biblical motif of God’s goodness (e.g., Ps 23:6 “et misericordia, et bonum” and Ps 31:19 “non est finis bonitatis tuae”), portraying the subject as the source of goodness.

Proslogion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nullus locus aut tempus te cohibet sed ubique et semper es
Proslogion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that no place or time can bind God and that He is everywhere at all times echoes Psalm 139:7‑10, where the psalmist asks where he can flee from God’s presence because God is in heaven, in Sheol, and everywhere.

The description of God as the only one who is “incircumscribed and eternal” parallels Revelation 1:8 (and 22:13) where Christ declares, “I am the Alpha and the Omega… the beginning and the end,” emphasizing divine unboundedness and eternity.

Proslogion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: si enim non esset anima tota in singulis membris sui corporis, non sentiret tota in singulis
Proslogion:13:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s analogy of a soul that would not be whole in each member of the body mirrors Paul’s teaching that the body is one and its many members are all part of the same whole (1 Cor 12:12‑14).
The formula “incircumscribed and eternal” recalls Psalm 90:2, which speaks of God’s existence “from everlasting to everlasting,” stressing divine eternity beyond spatial limits.

Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: An inuenisti, anima mea, quod quaerebas?
Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the Vulgate Psalm 27:8 “Dicite: Quaerite Dominum, et invenietis eum”, i.e. “Seek the Lord and you will find Him”.
Combines two Johannine self‑descriptions: “Ego sum via, veritas, et vita” (Jn 14:6) and “Ego sum lux mundi” (Jn 8:12), creating a merged image of Christ as light and truth.
Alludes to John 8:12 “Ego sum lux mundi”, the biblical claim that Christ is the light of the world, here paired with “veritas”.
Recalls John 1:5 “et lux in tenebris lucet”, the contrast of light and darkness that Anselm repeats in his meditation on divine illumination.

Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quanta namque est lux illa, de qua micas omne uerum quod rationali menti lucet!
Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes Psalm 119:105 “Lucerna pedibus meis verbum tuum, et lumen”, portraying divine truth as a light that guides the rational mind.

Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et a quo et per quem et quomodo de nihilo facta sunt
Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Paraphrases John 1:3 “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt”, extending it with the notion of creation “ex nihilo”.

Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: et a quo et per quem … de nihilo facta sunt
Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Resembles Hebrews 11:3 “Mundi facti sunt ex verbo Dei… non sunt facta ex his quae videntur”, linking Anselm’s discussion of divine truth to the biblical doctrine of creation out of nothing.

Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Domine deus meus, formator et reformator meus
Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes Psalm 100:3 “Scitote quoniam Dominus ipse est Deus: ipse fecit nos, et non nos ipsi”, presenting God as the ultimate creator (formator) and re‑creator (reformator).

Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quam ample est illa veritas, in qua est omne quod verum est
Proslogion:14:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Alludes to John 17:17 “Sanctifica eos in veritate tua”, expanding the biblical theme that all truth belongs to God.

Proslogion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non solum es quo maius cogitari nequit sed es quiddam maior quam cogitari possit
Proslogion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that God is greater than can be thought echoes Isaiah 55:8‑9 (Vulgate: “Quoniam cogitationes meæ non sunt cogitationes vestræ, nec viae vestrae viae meæ, dicit Dominus”), which stresses that divine thoughts and ways surpass human understanding.

Proslogion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non solum es quo maius cogitari nequit sed es quiddam maior quam cogitari possit
Proslogion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The language of God’s greatness beyond human conception parallels Psalm 145:3 (Vulgate: “Magnus Dominus, et laudabilis nimis; et magnitudo eius infinita”), which celebrates the Lord’s incomparably great nature.

Anselm’s remark that it is possible to think of something of this sort reflects Romans 11:33 (Vulgate: “O altitudo divitiarum sapientiae et scientiae Dei! Quam incomprehensibilia sunt iudicia eius, et investigabiles viæ eius!”), which marvels at the unfathomable depth of God’s wisdom.

Proslogion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: si tu non es hoc ipsum, potest cogitari aliquid maior te; quod fieri nequit
Proslogion:15:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that no greater thing than God can be thought mirrors Job 11:7 (Vulgate: “Numquid potest homo invenire profundum Dei?”), a rhetorical question about the impossibility of grasping God’s depth.

Proslogion:16:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s phrase echoes 1 Tim 6:16 “qui solus habet inmortale spiritum in luce inaccesibili” – the biblical description of God dwelling in unapproachable light.
The image of God as light that dwells in an inaccessible light recalls 1 Jn 1:5 “Deus est lux et in tenebris non est ullum” – God is light and there is no darkness in Him.

Proslogion:16:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Ubique es tota praesens, et non te video
Proslogion:16:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that God is everywhere yet unseen parallels Psalm 139:7‑8 “Unde fugiam a spiritu tuo? ubi fugiam a facie tua? … si ascendero in caelum, tu es illic; si descendero in infernum, non est a te.”

Proslogion:16:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Intra me et circa me es, et non te sentio
Proslogion:16:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The wording mirrors Psalm 139:9‑10, which speak of God’s presence everywhere (“If I take the wings of the dawn, if I dwell on the far side of the sea, even there your hand shall lead me”). Anselm’s phrasing stresses the same omnipresence coupled with the inability to perceive God.
John 1:18 states “Deum nemo vidit” – no one has seen God. Anselm’s lament “non te video” reflects this biblical claim that God is unseen by the creature.

Proslogion:16:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Non potest intellectus meus ad illam
Proslogion:16:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Isaiah 55:8‑9 declares that God’s thoughts and ways are higher than human ones; Anselm’s admission that his intellect cannot reach the divine light echoes this scriptural theme.

Proslogion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Circumspicit enim, et non uidet pulchritudinem tuam. Auscultat, et non audit harmoniam tuam. Olfacit, et non percipit odorem tuum. Gustat, et non cognoscit saporem tuum. Palpat, et non sentit lenitatem tuam.
Proslogion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s list of the five senses being dulled mirrors Isaiah 6:9‑10, where the prophet is told to say to the people, “Keep on hearing, but do not understand; keep on seeing, but do not perceive.” The structure and theme of sensory blindness are directly echoed.

Proslogion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Adhuc lates, domine, animam meam in luce et beatitudine tua, et idcirco versatur illa adhuc in tenebris et miseria sua.
Proslogion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The contrast between “light” and “darkness” recalls John 1:5 – “The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it.” Anselm’s language of the soul being in God’s light while the world remains in darkness reflects this Johannine motif.

Proslogion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: sed obriguerunt sed obstupuerunt sed obstructi sunt sensus animae meae vetusto languore peccati.
Proslogion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The description of the soul’s senses being “obstructed” and “stultified” by the “old languor of sin” parallels Romans 1:21‑22, where Paul says that humanity’s minds became futile and their hearts were darkened because of sin.

Proslogion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Habes enim haec, domine deus, in te tuo ineffabili modo, qui ea dedisti rebus a te creatis suo sensibili modo;
Proslogion:17:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The notion that God created all things “in his own sensible way” evokes the creation narrative of Genesis 1, especially the repeated phrase “and God said… and it was good,” though the wording is not a direct quotation.

Proslogion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quaesiui uultum tuum, uultum tuum, domine, requiem; ne auertas faciem tuam a me
Proslogion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reproduces almost verbatim the Vulgate Psalm 27:8 ("Quaerens faciem tuam, Domine, non avertas faciem tuam a me").
The phrase echoes Psalm 119:18 "Illumina oculos meos", re‑phrased to refer to the eye of the mind.
Anselm’s appeal "propter bonitatem tuam" recalls Psalm 86:5 "Quia bonum est tibi, Domine, misericordia tua" (the goodness of the Lord).
The statement that "all have sinned" mirrors Romans 3:23 "Omnes peccaverunt".
The idea that all have fallen echoes Romans 5:12, which links the fall of Adam to the universal condition of humanity.
The contrast between "light of God" and "darkness" recalls John 1:5 "et lux in tenebris lucet".

Proslogion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam quidquid partibus est iunctum, non est omnino unum ... sicut corpus unum est, et membra eius multa
Proslogion:18:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s discussion of parts and unity reflects 1 Cor 12:12’s image of one body with many members.

Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sed si per aeternitatem tuam fuisti et es et eris, ... quomodo aeternitas tua tota est semper?
Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of God’s eternal existence mirrors Psalm 90:2, which declares that God “is God from everlasting to everlasting,” emphasizing divine timelessness.

Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Sed si per aeternitatem tuam fuisti et es et eris
Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The tri‑adic formula “fuisti et es et eris” echoes the divine self‑identification “Ego sum qui sum” (I am who I am) in Exodus 3:14, re‑expressed in Anselm’s temporal language.

Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Non ergo fuisti heri aut eris cras sed heri et hodie et cras es.
Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that God is present “yesterday, today, and tomorrow” parallels Hebrews 13:8, which states that Christ “is the same yesterday, today, and forever.”

Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: tu autem, licet nihil sit sine te, non es tamen in loco aut tempore sed omnia sunt in te.
Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s assertion that “all things are in you” reflects Colossians 1:17, where Paul says that “by him all things were created, and in him all things hold together; without him nothing was made.”

Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nihil enim te continet sed tu confines omnia.
Proslogion:19:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that nothing contains God while God contains everything resonates with Psalm 139:7‑10, which asks where one can flee from God’s presence, implying God’s all‑encompassing nature.

Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: tu es ante omnia, quia antequam fierent tu es.
Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes Psalm 90:2 (Vulgate) “Priusquam montes nascerentur … a saeculo et usque in saeculum Deus,” expressing God’s existence before creation.

Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: tu es ante et ultra omnia.
Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Paraphrases Colossians 1:17 “Ipse est ante omnia, et omnia per ipsum constant,” adapting the formula “before all things” and adding “beyond all things.”

Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Qualiter enim es ultra ea quae finem non habebunt?
Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Recalls Revelation 1:8 “Ego sum Alpha et Omega, principium et finis,” the idea of God being beyond things that have no end.

Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: tua et illorum aeternitas tota tibi praesens est, cum illa nondum habeant de sua aeternitate quod venturum est
Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Parallels Hebrews 13:8 “Jesus Christus idem est, quod fuit, quod est, quod venturus est,” stressing the eternal presence of God while creatures await their own eternity.

Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: tu es ante omnia, quia antequam fierent tu es.
Proslogion:20:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes John 17:5 “… quod mihi erat ante saecula,” the claim that the divine exists before all created things.

Proslogion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm repeats the biblical formula “saeculum saeculorum” (the age of ages) that appears in 1 Tim 6:15 – “qui vivit in saeculo saeculorum”.

Proslogion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: "omnia sint te plena et sint in te"
Proslogion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The wording echoes Col 2:9, where Paul says that in Christ “habitat omnis plenitudo divinitatis corporaliter” – all fullness of God dwells in Him.

Proslogion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: "omnia sint te plena et sint in te"
Proslogion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The idea that everything is “full of” and “in” God recalls John 1:3’s claim that “Omnia per ipsum facta sunt, et sine ipso factum est nihil quod factum est”.

Proslogion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: "sine omni spatio, ut nec medium nec dimidium nec ulla pars sit in te"
Proslogion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of God as without space mirrors Psalm 139:6‑7, where the psalmist declares that there is no place where God cannot be present.

Proslogion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: "sine omni spatio, ut nec medium nec dimidium nec ulla pars sit in te"
Proslogion:21:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that no “part” can be in God reflects Jeremiah 23:24’s rhetorical question: “Is there any place where I may hide? … there is none that can hide from Me.”

Proslogion:22:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Tu solus ergo, domine, es quod es, et tu es qui es.
Proslogion:22:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s formula “es quod es, et tu es qui es” mirrors the Vulgate’s “Ego sum qui sum” (Exod. 3,14) used by God in the burning bush.
Anselm calls God “vita” (life), echoing Christ’s self‑designation “ego sum via, veritas, et vita” (John 14,6).
The attribute “lux” (light) recalls Jesus’ claim “ego sum lux mundi” (John 8,12).
Anselm’s identification of God with “sapientia” reflects the biblical equation of wisdom with the fear of the Lord (Prov. 9,10).
The term “beatitudo” (blessedness) evokes Psalm 1,1 “Beatus vir qui non abiit in consilio impiorum…”.
Anselm’s description of God as “aeternitas” parallels Psalm 90,2 “aeternam faciem tuam”.

Proslogion:22:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nec haloes fuisse aut futurum esse sed tantum praesens esse
Proslogion:22:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The claim that God is unchanging and only present mirrors Malachi 3,6 “Ego Dominus, non mutabor”.

Proslogion:22:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: tu tibi omnino sufficiens, nullo indigens, quo omnia indigent ut sint, et ut bene sint.
Proslogion:22:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s statement that God “sufficit sibi” and needs nothing reflects Psalm 50,12 “non est mihi quod desideres”.

Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Hoc bonum es tu, deus pater; hoc est verbum tuum, id est filius tuus.
Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm re‑states the prologue of John 1:1‑3, identifying the Father as the ultimate good and the Son as the Word (Verbum) of God.

Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quod est verum quomodo tu verax
Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The passage echoes Jesus’ claim in John 14:6 that He is the truth (veritas) and the true one, linking the divine nature of the Word with truth.

Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Hoc ipsum est amor unum et communis tibi et filio tuo, id est sanctus spiritus ab utroque procedens.
Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of the Holy Spirit proceeding from both Father and Son mirrors John 15:26, where the Spirit is sent by the Father in the name of the Son.

Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Hoc ipsum est amor unum et communis tibi et filio tuo, id est sanctus spiritus ab utroque procedens.
Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The formula ‘amor unum’ recalls 1 John 4:8, ‘Deus caritas est’, presenting divine love as a single, shared reality between Father and Son.
The statement ‘one is necessary’ reflects the Shema’s affirmation of the oneness of God (Deut 6:4).

Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quod est singulus quisque, hoc est tota trinitas simul, pater et filius et spiritus sanctus
Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s identification of the single ‘singulus quisque’ with the whole Trinity echoes the Trinitarian baptismal formula in Matthew 28:19.

Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: quondam verbum tnum sic est verum
Proslogion:23:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The phrase ‘the Word is true’ paraphrases John 1:14, where the Word (Verbum) becomes flesh and is identified with truth.

Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s appeal to the soul to “awaken” echoes Psalm 119:147 “Excita me in veritate tua”, a prayer for spiritual awakening.
The call to “raise up the whole intellect” parallels Proverbs 4:7 “Sapientia est principalis; ergo accipe sapientiam”, which urges the acquisition of wisdom.
Anselm’s phrase about the good that contains the joy of all goods reflects Psalm 16:11 “In tua praesentia est plenitudo gaudii”, which speaks of fullness of joy in God.

Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: tanto differentem quanto differt creator a creatura
Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The contrast between Creator and creature recalls Isaiah 40:28’s emphasis on the greatness of God compared with created things.

Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Si enim bona est vita creata: quam bona est vita creatrix?
Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The question about the goodness of created life versus the goodness of the life‑giver mirrors Genesis 2:7, where God forms man and breathes the breath of life into him.

Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Si iucunda est salus facta: quam iucunda est salus quae facit omnem salutem?
Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s meditation on the delight of salvation evokes John 3:16’s portrayal of God’s salvific love as the ultimate good.

Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Si amabilis est sapientia … quae omnia condidit ex nihilo?
Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The description of wisdom that creates all things from nothing directly paraphrases Proverbs 8:30, where wisdom is present before creation and participates in God’s creative act.

Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: qualis et quanta delectatio est in illo qui fecit ipsa delectabilia?
Proslogion:24:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The final question about the delight of the One who made all delights echoes Psalm 37:4 “Delectare in Domino, et dabitur tibi desideria cordis tui”.

Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nec oculus uidit nec auris audiuit nec cor hominis
Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm re‑words the Vulgate wording of 1 Cor 2:9 (“quae oculis non viderunt, et aures non audierunt, et non introierunt in cor hominis”).
The phrase echoes Psalm 37:6 where the Vulgate says “et erunt iusti sicut sol in splendorem suum”.
A similar image occurs in Psalm 8:5 (“et erunt sicut angeli”), though the exact wording is not found; Anselm’s clause is a thematic echo.

Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: seminatur corpus animale, et surget corpus spirituale
Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Close to 1 Cor 15:44: “Seminatur corpus animale, et resurget corpus spirituale”.
Reflects Psalm 37:29 (“iusti habitabunt in terra in sempiternum”), rendered here as “iusti in perpetnum uiunt”.
Exact wording of Psalm 37:39 in the Vulgate: “Salus iustorum a Domino”.
Paraphrases Psalm 36:9 (“inebriabuntur de abundantia domus tuae”).

Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: angelorum chori concinunt sine fine deo
Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Alludes to the perpetual praise of God by the angels (Rev 5:13), though the exact Latin phrasing is not found in the Vulgate.

Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: torrente uoluptatis suae potabit eos deus
Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Resembles Psalm 36:8’s image of a “stream of sweetness” (torrente dulcedinis) that God provides, but the wording is Anselm’s own.
Exact phrase from John 1:12 (“et facti sunt filii Dei”).
Echoes Psalm 82:6 (“Ego dixi: ‘Dii estis’”), where the term “dii” is applied to human judges; Anselm adapts it to a future naming.

Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: heredes quidem dei, coheredes autem Christi
Proslogion:25:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Exact wording of Romans 8:17 in the Vulgate: “heredes quidem Dei, coheredes autem Christi”.

Proslogion:26:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Petite et accipietis, ut gaudium uestrum sit plenum.
Proslogion:26:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes the promise of the Gospel of Matthew 7:7, where Jesus says “Petite, et dabitur vobis…”, here rendered as “Petite et accipietis”.

Proslogion:26:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nec oculus uidit, nec auris audiuit, nec in cor hominis ascendit
Proslogion:26:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: A near‑verbatim quotation of the Vulgate wording of 1 Cor 2:9: “Nihil oculis vidit, nec auribus audivit, nec in corde hominis ascendit”.

Pro_insipiente:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: Anselm’s claim that a nature must exist in which ‘nothing evil can be thought’ echoes the Genesis passage in which God forbids eating from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, linking the possibility of thinking about evil to a created order that permits it.

Pro_insipiente:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: malus est esse et in re quam in solo intellectu
Pro_insipiente:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: The contrast between evil existing ‘in reality’ versus merely in the intellect recalls Paul’s distinction in Romans 8:6 between the mind set on the flesh (death) and the mind set on the spirit (life), suggesting that true evil must have a concrete, not merely mental, existence.

Anselm’s statement that ‘evil must be for all’ resonates with the post‑Fall declaration in Genesis 3:17 that ‘the ground shall be cursed, and there shall be thorns and thistles for all the earth,’ indicating a universal presence of evil after the fall.

Pro_insipiente:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: non eo modo posse cogitari non esse, quo etiam potest non esse deus.
Pro_insipiente:2:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: Anselm’s claim that something can be thought not to exist in the same way that God can be thought not to exist echoes Psalm 14:1 (and its parallel Psalm 53:1) where the fool says, “There is no God.” The passage uses the same logical contrast between the possibility of conceiving non‑existence and the denial of God’s existence.

Pro_insipiente:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: quia et sicut sanctus Augustinus ait: Cum faber arcam facturus in opere, prius habet illam in arte; arca quae fit in opere non est uita, arca quae est in arte uita est, quia uiuit anima artificis, in qua sunt ista omnia, antequam proferantur.
Pro_insipiente:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: Anselm’s description of the “life” of the picture existing in the artist’s mind echoes Genesis 2:7, where God gives the “breath of life” to man, indicating that life is imparted by the creator’s spirit before the physical form appears.

Pro_insipiente:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: Quocirca etiam si uerum sit esse aliquid quo maius quicquam nequeat cogitari: non tamen hoc auditum et intellectum tale est qualis nondum: facta pictura in intellectu pictoris.
Pro_insipiente:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: The passage that the “true thing” is apprehended by the intellect, though not yet manifested, parallels Romans 1:20, which states that the invisible qualities of God are clearly seen and understood through the created world.

Pro_insipiente:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: Unde nec illud exemplum de pictore picturam quam facturus est iam in intellectu habente, satis potest huic argumento congruere.
Pro_insipiente:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: The notion that the picture exists in the painter’s intellect before being made reflects John 1:1’s claim that “the Word was with God… and the Word was God,” i.e., the Logos (the divine idea) pre‑exists the material creation.

Pro_insipiente:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: Aliud sine dubio est uerum illud, aliud intellectus ipse quo capitur.
Pro_insipiente:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: The contrast between “truth” and the “intellect that captures it” resonates with Psalm 119:105’s metaphor of God’s word being a lamp to the mind, though the wording is not a direct quotation.

Pro_insipiente:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: quod nihil aliud posse esse dicitur quam ipse deus
Pro_insipiente:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: Anselm’s claim that nothing can be said to exist except God echoes Deut 4,35 “Tu es Deus, et non est alius” (You are God, there is no other).

Pro_insipiente:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: Nam si de homine aliquo mihi prorsus ignoto, quem etiam esse nescirem, dici tamen aliquid audirem
Pro_insipiente:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: The contrast between an unknown human that can still be spoken of and God that cannot be thought of reflects Isaiah 45,5 “Ego sum Dominus, et non est alius” (I am the LORD, and there is no other).

Pro_insipiente:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: cum audio intelligoque dicentem esse aliquid maius omnibus quae ualeant cogitari
Pro_insipiente:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: Anselm’s meditation on a being “greater than all that can be thought” parallels Romans 11,33 which praises the “depths of the riches of the wisdom and knowledge of God,” a wisdom beyond human thought.

Pro_insipiente:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: non tam vox ipsa quae res est utique vera, hoc est litterarum sonus uel syllabarum, quam uocis auditue significatio cogitetur
Pro_insipiente:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: The distinction Anselm draws between the sound of words and the true reality they signify recalls John 1,1 “In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum,” where the Word (Verbum) is more than mere sound.

Pro_insipiente:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: non potes ultra dubitare ... non ambigis esse
Pro_insipiente:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: Anselm’s claim that one cannot doubt the existence of the island and that its reality exceeds mere intellect echoes Hebrews 11:1, which defines faith as "the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen."

Pro_insipiente:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.anselm_text: non potes ultra dubitare ... non ambigis esse
Pro_insipiente:6:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: The passage’s insistence that one must not doubt the island’s existence parallels Mark 11:23, where Jesus says that if one does not doubt in the heart, the spoken word will be accomplished.
The description of a “lost” island recalls the parable of the lost sheep (Luke 15:4), using the motif of something valuable that is missing and sought.

Anselm’s remark that the island has no possessor or inhabitant evokes Matthew 6:24’s teaching that no one can serve two masters, suggesting the impossibility of ownership over something that truly belongs to God.

Pro_insipiente:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: Anselm’s use of the adjective *insipiens* to describe the foolish opponent echoes Psalm 14:1 (and its parallel Psalm 53:1) where the psalmist says, “Dixit insipiens in corde suo: non est Deus.” The passage alludes to the biblical motif of the foolish man who denies God.

Pro_insipiente:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exa.explanation: Anselm’s image of a “fragrant odor” of pious affection echoes the biblical metaphor of believers being the “odor of Christ” (2 Cor 2:15, Vulgate), where fragrance signifies the pleasant, holy influence of the faithful.

The adjective “magnifice” (magnificently) recalls the Psalmist’s declaration “Magnus Dominus, et laudabilis nimis” (Psalm 145:3), a formula that links greatness with praise and is often used by Anselm to describe divine‑like excellence in writing.

The call to receive everything “with great reverence and praise” reflects Deuteronomy 10:12’s exhortation to “timorem Domini” (great awe of the Lord) and the surrounding language of worship, a theme Anselm repeatedly adapts for the proper attitude toward theological truth.

Responsio:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non est in intellectu aliquid quo maius cogitari non possit
Responsio:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that nothing greater can be thought mirrors Psalm 145:3 – “Great is the LORD, and greatly to be praised; his greatness cannot be measured,” expressing the same theological idea of an incomparably great God.

Responsio:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: nullus negans aut dubitans esse aliquid quo maior cogitari non possit
Responsio:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The insistence that no one can deny the existence of something greater than can be thought echoes Hebrews 13:8, “Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever,” which stresses the unchanging, unsurpassable nature of God.

Responsio:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam quod heri non fuit et hodie est
Responsio:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s contrast of what “was not yesterday and is today” parallels the same wording in Hebrews 13:8, emphasizing the continuity and constancy of divine truth.

Responsio:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nam et si dicatur tempus semper esse et mundus ubique, non tamen illud totum semper aut i…
Responsio:1:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The discussion of an eternal, all‑present world recalls Isaiah 40:28’s description of God who “measures the heavens and the earth; he is the one who is not weary, and his understanding is unsearchable,” suggesting an all‑encompassing divine order.

Responsio:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: non potest cogitari non esse 'quo maior nequit cogitari'
Responsio:3:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Echoes Psalm 145:3 (Vulgate) “Maiorem quam ipse non est”, i.e., nothing greater than God can be thought; Anselm’s phrase “quo maior nequit cogitari” mirrors this claim of an unsurpassable greatness.
Paraphrases Psalm 139:6 “Non est abscondere a te locum, quod non possit inveniri”, employing the same idea of something that cannot be found or discovered.

Alludes to the parable of the lost sheep/coin (Luke 15:4‑8) where the Greek word “ἀπολωλὼς” is rendered in the Vulgate as “perditus”; Anselm’s “perditam insulam” evokes the notion of something lost that must be recovered.

Responsio:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Falsum est enim non esse quod est.
Responsio:4:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s statement that ‘it is false that what is does not exist’ echoes Psalm 14:1 (and its parallel Psalm 53:1) where the foolish one declares ‘There is no God.’ Anselm is re‑phrasing the biblical denial of God’s existence as a falsehood.

Responsio:5:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s repeated claim that something is “greater than all” echoes the Psalmist’s declaration “Great is the LORD, and greatly to be praised; his greatness is beyond all” (Psalm 95:3), using the same superlative language to point to the ultimate greatness of God.

The formula “that which is greater is in the intellect, and therefore in reality” recalls the prologue of John, where the Logos is first presented as existing “in the beginning” and then becoming flesh (John 1:1‑14), linking the intellectual (the Word) with actual being.

Responsio:5:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quod non est, potest non esse; et quod non esse potest, cogitari potest non esse.
Responsio:5:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s observation that what does not exist can be thought not to exist resonates with Paul’s rhetorical question “If God is for us, who can be against us?” (Rom 8:31), which uses the logical move from existence to impossibility of opposition.

Responsio:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: negat deum, cuius sensum nullo modo cogitat
Responsio:7:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s description of someone who “denies God, whose sense cannot be thought of at all” echoes Psalm 14:1 (and its parallel Psalm 53:1) where the fool says, “There is no God.” The passage parallels the biblical motif of the fool’s denial of God.

The claim that God is “not at all understood” reflects Romans 1:20, which teaches that although God is invisible, His existence and attributes are clearly evident in creation, i.e., known even when not fully comprehended.

Anselm’s remark that God’s sense “cannot be thought of” and that He is “not at all intelligible” loosely resonates with 1 Timothy 1:17’s description of God as “incognitus” (unknown) and “invisibilis,” emphasizing the limits of human cognition concerning the divine.

Responsio:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: invisibilia dei a creatura mundi per ea, quae facta sunt, intellecta conspicuntur, sempiterna quoque eius uirtus et diuinitas
Responsio:8:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm reproduces verbatim the Vulgate wording of Romans 1:20, differing only in the u/v orthography (uirtus vs virtus).

Responsio:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Quisquis igitur negat aliquid esse quo maius nequeat cogitari: utique intelligit et cogitat negationem quam facit.
Responsio:9:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that there is something greater than which nothing greater can be thought mirrors the biblical affirmation of God’s uniqueness – “Tu es Deus, et non est alius” (Deut 4:35). Both express that the supreme being is beyond any greater conception.

Responsio:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Nihil autem huiusmodi non esse potest, quo maior aliquid cogitari non potest.
Responsio:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: Anselm’s claim that nothing can exist that cannot be thought mirrors Jeremiah 32:17 (Vulgate): “Ah! si potero facere aliquid, et non erit in me, et non erit in me,” i.e., “Nothing is impossible for God.” Both express the idea that the divine power makes any conceivable thing possible.

Responsio:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Verbi gratia: melius est esse aeternum quam non aeternum, bonum quam non bonum, immo bonitatem ipsam quam non ipsam bonitatem.
Responsio:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The contrast between eternal existence and non‑eternal existence echoes the Johannine promise of “et vitam aeternam” (and eternal life) in John 3:16, though Anselm does not quote the verse directly.

Responsio:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.anselm_text: Credimus namque de diuina substantia quodquid absolute cogitari potest melius esse quam non esse.
Responsio:10:openai_gpt-oss-120b:exacto.explanation: The assertion that whatever can be fully thought of of God’s substance is better than non‑existence reflects Psalm 90:2’s affirmation of God’s eternal, self‑existent nature (“a Deo natus est”) and the biblical theme that God’s being is the ultimate good.
